A002001.name: a(n) = 3*4^(n-1), n>0; a(0)=1.
formula: With interpolated zeros, this has e.g.f. (3*cosh(2*x) + 1)/4 and binomial transform A006342. - _Paul Barry_, Sep 03 2003
a(n) = Sum_{j=0..1} Sum_{k=0..n} C(2n+j, 2k). - _Paul Barry_, Nov 29 2003
Row sums of triangle A134316. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Oct 19 2007

If p[1]=3, p[i]=3, (i>1), and if A is Hessenberg matrix of order n defined by: A[i,j]=p[j-i+1], (i<=j), A[i,j]=-1, (i=j+1), and A[i,j]=0 otherwise. Then, for n>=1, a(n)=det A. - _Milan Janjic_, Apr 29 2010
G.f.: 1 - G(0) where G(k) = 1 - 1/(1-3*x)/(1-x/(x-1/G(k+1) )); (recursively defined continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jan 25 2013
G.f.: x+2*x/(G(0)-2), where G(k) = 1 + 1/(1 - x*(3*k+1)/(x*(3*k+4) + 1/G(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, May 26 2013

Construct the power matrix T(n,j)=[A(n)^*j]*[S(n)^*(j-1)] where A(n)=(3,3,3...) and S(n)=(0,1,0,0...). (* is convolution operation). Then T(n,j) counts n-walks containing j loops on the single vertex graph above and a(n) = Sum_{j=1...n} T(n,j). (S(n)^*0=I.) - _David Neil McGrath_, Jan 01 2015

A002002.name: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n-1} binomial(n,k+1) * binomial(n+k,k).
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n-1} binomial(n-1, k)*binomial(n+k, k+1). - _Paul Barry_, Sep 20 2004
a(n) = n * hypergeom([n + 1, -n + 1], [2], -1) = (n+1)*LegendreP(n+1,3) - (5*n+3)*LegendreP(n,3))/(2*n) for n>0. - _Mark van Hoeij_, Jul 12 2010
a(n) = -a(-n) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Aug 09 2011
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} A201701(n,k)^2 = Sum_{k=0..n} A124182(n,k)^2 for n>0. - _Philippe Deléham_, Dec 05 2011

a(n) = (-1)^(n-1)*Sum_{k=0..n-1}(-2)^k*binomial(n-1,k)*binomial(n+k,k) and n^3*a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n-1}(4*k^3+4*k^2+4*k+1)*binomial(n-1,k)*binomial(n+k,k). For each of the two equalities, both sides satisfy the same recurrence - this follows from the Zeilberger algorithm. - _Zhi-Wei Sun_, Aug 30 2014
a(n) = hypergeom([1-n, -n], [1], 2) for n>=1. - _Peter Luschny_, Nov 19 2014
Logarithmic derivative of A001003 (little Schroeder numbers). - _Paul D. Hanna_, May 17 2015
L.g.f.: L(x) = Sum_{n>=1} d^(n-1)/dx^(n-1) x^(2*n-1) * (1-x)^(-n) / n! = Sum_{n>=1} a(n)*x^n/n where exp(L(x)) = g.f. of A001003. - _Paul D. Hanna_, May 17 2015
a(n+1) = (1/2^(n+1)) * Sum_{k = 0..inf} (1/2^k) * binomial(n + k, n)*binomial(n + k, n + 1). - _Peter Bala_, Mar 02 2017

A002003.name: a(n) = 2 * Sum_{k=0..n-1} binomial(n-1, k)*binomial(n+k, k).
formula: a(n) = T(n, n-1), array T as in A064861.
a(n) = T(n, n-2), array T as in A049600.
a(n) = 2 * JacobiP(n-1,0,1,3) = ((7*n+3)*LegendreP(n,3) - (n+1)*LegendreP(n+1,3)) /(2*n) for n>0. - _Mark van Hoeij_, Jul 12 2010
Logarithmic derivative of A006318, the large Schroeder numbers. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Oct 25 2010
D-finite with recurrence: 4*(3*n^2-6*n+2)*a(n-1) - (n-2)*(2*n-1)*a(n-2) - n*(2*n-3)*a(n)=0. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Oct 04 2012
a(n) = Hyper2F1([-n, n], [1], -1) for n>0. - _Peter Luschny_, Aug 02 2014

Conjecture: a(n) = - [x^n] (1 - F(x))^n, where F(x) = 2*x + 6*x^2 + 34*x^3 + 238*x^4 + ... is the o.g.f. of A108424. Equivalently, a(n) = -[x^n](G(x))^(-n), where G(x) = 1 + 2*x + 10*x^2 + 66*x^3 + 498*x^4 + ... is the o.g.f. of A027307.
Supercongruences: a(p) == 2 ( mod p^3 ) for prime p >= 5. (End)
a(n) = Sum_{k = 1..n} C(n, k) * C(n-1, k-1) * 2^k. - _Michael Somos_, May 23 2021

A002004.name: Davenport-Schinzel numbers of degree 4 on n symbols.

A002005.name: Number of rooted planar cubic maps with 2n vertices.
formula: D-finite with recurrence (n+2)*(n+1)*a(n) -48*(3*n-2)*(3*n-4)*a(n-2)=0. - _R. J. Mathar_, Feb 08 2021

A002011.name: a(n) = 4*(2n+1)!/n!^2.
formula: a(n) = 1/J(n) where J(n) = Integral_{t=0..Pi/4} (cos(t)^2 - 1/2)^(2n+1). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Oct 17 2006

A002014.name: Number of symmetric filaments with n square cells.

A002015.name: a(n) = n^2 reduced mod 100.
formula: a(n) = (n mod 10) * ((n mod 10) + 20 * ((n\10) mod 10)) mod 100. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Mar 21 2010

A002016.name: Number of first n tetrahedral numbers (A000292) that are relatively prime to n.
formula: a(n) = number of b(1), ..., b(n) that are relatively prime to n, where b() = A000292().

A002017.name: E.g.f. exp(sin(x)).
formula: a(n) = D^n(exp(x)) evaluated at x = 0, where D is the operator sqrt(1-x^2)*d/dx. Cf. A003724. - _Peter Bala_, Dec 06 2011
E.g.f.: 1 + sin(x)/T(0), where T(k) = 4*k+1 - sin(x)/(2 + sin(x)/(4*k+3 - sin(x)/(2 + sin(x)/T(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Dec 03 2013
E.g.f.: 2/Q(0), where Q(k) = 1 + 1/( 1 - sin(x)/( sin(x) - (k+1)/Q(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Dec 16 2013
E.g.f.: E(0)-1, where E(k) = 2 + sin(x)/(2*k + 1 - sin(x)/E(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Dec 23 2013

A002019.name: a(n) = a(n-1) - (n-1)(n-2)a(n-2).
formula: a(n) = n!*sum(if oddp(m+n) then 0 else (-1)^((3*n+m)/2)/(2^m*m!)*sum(2^i*binomial(n-1,i-1)*m!/i!*stirling1(i,m),i,m,n),m,1,n), n>0. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Aug 05 2010
E.g.f.: exp(arctan(x)) = 1 + 2x/(H(0)-x); H(k) = 4k + 2 + x^2*(4k^2 + 8k + 5)/H(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Nov 15 2011
a(n+1) = a(n) - a(n-1) * A002378(n-2). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Feb 27 2012
E.g.f.: -2i*(B((1+ix)/2; (2-i)/2, (2+i)/2) - B(1/2; (2-i)/2, (2+i)/2)), for a(0)=0, a(1)=a(2)=a(3)=1, B(x;a,b) is the incomplete Beta function. - _G. C. Greubel_, May 01 2015
a(n) = i^n*n!*Sum_{r+s=n} (-1)^s*binomial(-i/2, r)*binomial(i/2,s) where i is the imaginary unit. See the Fib. Quart. link. - _Michel Marcus_, Jan 22 2017

A002020.name: a(n+1) = a(n) - n*(n-1)*a(n-1), with a(n) = 1 for n <= 3.

A002021.name: Pile of coconuts problem: (n-1)(n^n - 1), n even; n^n - n + 1, n odd.
formula: E.g.f.: (1-x)*exp(x)-(W(x)+2)*(2*W(x)+1)/(2*(1+W(x))^3)-W(-x)/(2*(1+W(-x))^3) where W is the Lambert W function. - _Robert Israel_, Aug 26 2016

A002024.name: n appears n times; a(n) = floor(sqrt(2n) + 1/2).
formula: a(n) = floor( 1/2 + sqrt(2n) ). Also a(n) = ceiling((sqrt(1+8n)-1)/2). [See the Liu link for a large collection of explicit formulas. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Oct 30 2019]
a((k - 1 ) * k / 2 + i) = k for k > 0 and 0 < i <= k. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Aug 30 2001
a(n) = a(n - a(n-1)) + 1, with a(1)=1. - Ian M. Levitt (ilevitt(AT)duke.poly.edu), Aug 18 2002
a(n) = round(sqrt(2n)). - Antonio G. Astudillo (afg_astudillo(AT)hotmail.com), Nov 01 2002
Equals A127899 * A004736. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Feb 09 2007
a(n) = sum{i=0..n-1, A010054(i)}. - _Paolo P. Lava_, Apr 02 2007
Sum_{i=1..n} Sum_{j=i..n+i-1} T(j,i) = A000578(n); Sum_{i=1..n} T(n,i) = A000290(n). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jun 24 2007

We know that a(n)=round(sqrt(2n))=round(sqrt(2*n-1)); now exist exactly a and b greater than zero, that: 2n = 2+(a+b)^2 -(a+3*b), we have: a(n)=(a+b-1) in closed formula. - Fabio Civolani (civox(AT)tiscali.it), Feb 23 2010
Expansion of psi(x) * x / (1 - x) in powers of x where psi() is a Ramanujan theta function. - _Michael Somos_, Mar 19 2014
G.f.: x/(1-x) * Product_{n>=1} (1 + x^n) * (1 - x^(2*n)). - _Paul D. Hanna_, Feb 27 2016
a(n) = 1 + Sum{i=1..n/2} ceiling(floor(2(n-1)/(i^2+i))/(2n)). - _José de Jesús Camacho Medina_, Jan 07 2017

A002025.name: Smaller of an amicable pair: (a,b) such that sigma(a)=sigma(b)=a+b, a<b.

A002026.name: Generalized ballot numbers (first differences of Motzkin numbers).
formula: Number of (s(0), s(1), ..., s(n)) such that s(i) is a nonnegative integer, s(0) = 0 = s(n), s(1) = 1, |s(i) - s(i-1)| <= 1 for i >= 2, Also T(n, n), where T is the array defined in A026105.
D-finite with recurrence: (n+3)*a(n) +(-3*n-4)*a(n-1) +(-n-1)*a(n-2) +3*(n-2)*a(n-3)=0. - _R. J. Mathar_, Dec 03 2012
G.f.: A(z) satisfies z*A(z) = (1-z)*M(z) - 1, where M(z) is the g.f. of A001006. - _Gennady Eremin_, Feb 09 2021

A002027.name: Number of connected graphs on n labeled nodes, each node being colored with one of 2 colors, such that no edge joins nodes of the same color.
formula: a(n) = m_n(2) using the functions defined in A002032. - _Sean A. Irvine_, May 29 2013
E.g.f.: log(A(x))+1 where A(x) is the e.g.f. for A047863. - _Geoffrey Critzer_, Sep 05 2013
Logarithmic transform of A047863. - _Andrew Howroyd_, Dec 03 2018

A002028.name: Number of connected graphs on n labeled nodes, each node being colored with one of 3 colors, such that no edge joins nodes of the same color.
formula: E.g.f.: log(A(x))+1 where A(x) is the e.g.f. for A191371. - _Geoffrey Critzer_, Jun 02 2011
a(n) = m_n(3) using the functions defined in A002032. - _Sean A. Irvine_, May 29 2013
Logarithmic transform of A191371. - _Andrew Howroyd_, Dec 03 2018

A002029.name: Number of connected graphs on n labeled nodes, each node being colored with one of 4 colors, such that no edge joins nodes of the same color.
formula: E.g.f.: log(b(x)+1)+1 where b(x) = 4 * e.g.f. of A000686. - _Sean A. Irvine_, May 27 2013
a(n) = m_n(4) using the functions defined in A002032. - _Sean A. Irvine_, May 29 2013
Logarithmic transform of A223887. - _Andrew Howroyd_, Dec 03 2018

A002030.name: Number of connected graphs on n labeled nodes, each node being colored with one of 5 colors, such that no edge joins nodes of the same color.
formula: E.g.f.: log(B(x)+1) where B(x) = Sum_{n>=0} b(n)x^n/n! and b(n) = Sum_{j=0..n} C(n, j)*2^(j*(n-j)+2)*A000686(j). - _Sean A. Irvine_, May 27 2013
a(n) = m_n(5) using the functions defined in A002032. - _Sean A. Irvine_, May 29 2013

A002031.name: Number of labeled connected digraphs where every node has indegree 0 or outdegree 0 and no isolated nodes.
formula: a(n) = f(n,2) using functions defined in A002032. - _Sean A. Irvine_, May 29 2013

A002032.name: Number of n-colored connected graphs on n labeled nodes.
formula: Define M_0(k)=1, M_n(0)=0, M_n(k) = Sum_{r=0..n} C(n,r)*2^(r*(n-r))*M_r(k-1) [M_n(k) = A322280(n,k)], m_n(k) = M_n(k) -Sum_{r=1..n-1} C(n-1,r-1)*m_r(k)*M_{n-r}(k) [m_n(k) = A322279(n,k)], f_n(k) = Sum_{r=1..k} (-1)^(k-r)*C(k,r)*m_n(r). This sequence gives a(n) = f_n(n). - _Sean A. Irvine_, May 29 2013, edited _Andrew Howroyd_, Dec 03 2018
The above formula is referenced by sequences A002027-A002030, A002031. - _Andrew Howroyd_, Dec 03 2018

A002033.name: Number of perfect partitions of n.

A002034.name: Kempner numbers: smallest positive integer m such that n divides m!.
formula: The following identities were given by Kempner (1918):
a(p1 * p2 * ... * pu) = pu if p1 < p2 < ... < pu are distinct primes.
a(p^k) = p * k for p prime and k <= p.
Let n = p1^e1 * p2^e2 * ... * pu^eu be the canonical factorization of n, then a(n) = max( a(p1^e1), a(p2^e2), ..., a(pu^eu) ).

Clearly a(n) >= P(n), the largest prime factor of n (= A006530). a(n) = P(n) for almost all n (Erdős and Kastanas 1994, Ivic 2004). The exceptions are A057109. a(n) = P(n) if and only if a(n) is prime because if a(n) > P(n) and a(n) were prime, then since n divides a(n)!, n would also divide (a(n)-1)!, contradicting minimality of a(n). - _Jonathan Sondow_, Jan 10 2005

If p is prime then a(p^k) = k*p for 0 <= k <= p. Hence it appears also that if n = 2^m * p(1)^e(1) * ... * p(r)^e(r) and if there exists b, 1 <= b <= r, such that Max(2 * m + 2, p(i) * e(i), 1 <= i <= r) = p(b) * e(b) with e(b) <= p(b) then a(n) = e(b) * p(b). E.g.: a(2145986896455317997802121296896) = a(2^10 * 3^3 * 7^9 * 11^9 * 13^8) = 13 * 8 = 104, since 8 * 13 = Max (2 * 10 + 2, 3 * 3, 7 * 9, 11 * 9, 13 * 8) and 8 <= 13. - _Benoit Cloitre_, Sep 01 2002
It appears that a(2^m - 1) is the largest prime factor of 2^m - 1 (A005420).
a(n!) = n for all n > 0 and a(p) = p if p is prime. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Dec 23 2004
Conjecture: a(n) = 1 + n - Sum_{k=1..n} Sum_{m=1..n} cos(-2*Pi*k/n*m!)/n. Formula verified for the 500 first terms. - _Mats Granvik_, Feb 26 2021

A002035.name: Numbers that contain primes to odd powers only.

A002036.name: Compressed primes: a(n) is the nearest integer to prime(n)/log prime(n).

A002037.name: Product of all primes up to 3^n.

A002038.name: Numbers dividing A002037(i) and larger than A002037(i-1), for some i>0.

A002039.name: Convolution inverse of A143348.
formula: G.f.: -x / (Sum_{k>0} k * (-x)^k / (1 - (-x)^k)) = 1 / (log( f(x) )') where f(-x) = Product_{k>0} (1 - x^k) is one of Ramanujan's theta functions. - _Michael Somos_, Apr 08 2003
a(0) = 1; a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} (-1)^(k+1) * sigma(k+1) * a(n-k). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, May 27 2020

A002040.name: Related to partitions.
formula: G.f.: 1/(f(q)') where f(-q)=Product_{k>0} (1-q^k) is one of Ramanujan's theta functions. - _Michael Somos_, Apr 08 2003

A002047.name: Number of 3 X (2n+1) zero-sum arrays with entries -n,..,0,..,n.

A002048.name: Segmented numbers, or prime numbers of measurement.
formula: Andrews conjectures that lim_{n -> oo} n log n / (a(n) loglog n) = 1. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Dec 01 2013

A002049.name: Prime numbers of measurement.
formula: Andrews conjectures that a(n) ~ (1/2) n^2 log n / loglog n. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Dec 01 2013

A002050.name: Number of simplices in barycentric subdivision of n-simplex.
formula: a(n) = 1 + 2*Sum_{k=2..n} k!*Stirling2(n,k), n > 0, a(0)=1. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Sep 27 2013
G.f.: T(0)/(1-2*x) - 1/(1-x), where T(k) = 1 - 2*x^2*(k+1)^2/(2*x^2*(k+1)^2 - (1 - 2*x - 3*x*k)*(1 - 5*x - 3*x*k)/T(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Nov 29 2013
G.f.: Sum_{j>=1} j!*x^j / Product_{k=0..j} (1 - (k + 1)*x). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Apr 04 2019

A002051.name: Steffensen's bracket function [n,2].
formula: a(1)=0; for n >= 2, a(n) = A000670(n-1) - 2^(n-2). - Manfred Goebel (mkgoebel(AT)essex.ac.uk), Feb 20 2000; formula adjusted by _N. J. A. Sloane_, Apr 22 2014. For example, a(5) = 67 = A000670(4)-2^3 = 75-8 = 67.
E.g.f.: (1 - exp(2*x) - 2*log(2 - exp(x)))/4 = B(A(x)) where A(x) = exp(x)-1 and B(x) = (log(1/(1-x))- x - x^2/2)/2. - _Geoffrey Critzer_, Nov 23 2012

A002052.name: Prime determinants of forms with class number 2.

A002053.name: a(n) = least value of m for which Liouville's function A002819(m) = -n.

A002054.name: Binomial coefficient C(2n+1, n-1).
formula: a(n) = Sum_{j=0..n-1} binomial(2*j, j) * binomial(2*n -2*j, n-j-1)/(j+1). - Yong Kong (ykong(AT)curagen.com), Dec 26 2000
G.f.: z*C^4/(2-C), where C=[1-sqrt(1-4z)]/(2z) is the Catalan function. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Jul 05 2003
G.f.: z*C(z)^3/(1-2*z*C(z)), where C(z) is the g.f. of Catalan numbers. - _José Luis Ramírez Ramírez_, Apr 19 2015
D-finite with recurrence: a(n+1) = a(n)*(2*n+3)*(2*n+2)/(n*(n+3)). - _Chai Wah Wu_, Jan 26 2016

A002055.name: Number of diagonal dissections of a convex n-gon into n-4 regions.
formula: With offset 0, this has a(n)=(n+2)*C(2n+4,n)/2 and e.g.f. dif(dif(x*dif(exp(2x)*Bessel_I(2,2x),x),x),x)/2. - _Paul Barry_, Aug 25 2007

A002056.name: Number of diagonal dissections of a convex n-gon into n-5 regions.
formula: D-finite with recurrence: -(n-1)*(n-5)*(n-6)*a(n) +2*(2*n-7)*(n-3)*(n-4)*a(n-1)=0. - _R. J. Mathar_, Feb 16 2020

A002057.name: Fourth convolution of Catalan numbers: 4*binomial(2n+3,n)/(n+4).
formula: G.f.: c(x)^4 with c(x) g.f. of A000108 (Catalan).

Row sums of A145596. Column 4 of A033184. By specializing the identities for the row polynomials given in A145596 we obtain the results a(n) = Sum_{k = 0..n} (-1)^k*binomial(n+1,k+1)*a(k)*4^(n-k) and a(n) = Sum_{k = 0..floor(n/2)} binomial(n+1,2*k+1) * Catalan(k+1) * 2^(n-2*k). From the latter identity we can derive the congruences a(2n+1) == 0 (mod 4) and a(2n) == Catalan(n+1) (mod 4). It follows that a(n) is odd if and only if n = (2^m - 4) for some m >= 2. - _Peter Bala_, Oct 14 2008

Let A be the Toeplitz matrix of order n defined by: A[i,i-1]=-1, A[i,j]=Catalan(j-i), (i<=j), and A[i,j]=0, otherwise. Then, for n>=3, a(n-3)=(-1)^(n-3)*coeff(charpoly(A,x),x^3). - _Milan Janjic_, Jul 08 2010
D-finite with recurrence: (n+4)*a(n) + 2*(-3*n-7)*a(n-1) + 4*(2*n+1)*a(n-2) = 0. - _R. J. Mathar_, Jun 03 2014
a(n) = C(n+1)-2*C(n) where C is Catalan number A000108. _Yuchun Ji_, Oct 18 2017 [Note: Offset is off by 2]

A002058.name: Number of internal triangles in all triangulations of an (n+1)-gon.

A002059.name: Number of partitions of a n-gon into (n-4) parts.

A002060.name: Number of partitions of a n-gon into (n-5) parts.

A002061.name: Central polygonal numbers: a(n) = n^2 - n + 1.
formula: a(n) = A000217(n) + A000217(n-2) (sum of two triangular numbers).
a(n) = ceiling((n-1/2)^2). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Apr 16 2003. [Hence the terms are about midway between successive squares and so (except for 1) are not squares. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Nov 01 2005]
a(n) = floor(t(n^2)/t(n)), where t(n) = A000217(n). - _Jon Perry_, Feb 14 2004
a(n) = leftmost term in M^(n-1) * [1 1 1], where M = the 3 X 3 matrix [1 1 1 / 0 1 2 / 0 0 1]. E.g., a(6) = 31 since M^5 * [1 1 1] = [31 11 1]. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Nov 11 2004

a(n+1) = n^2 + n + 1. a(n+1)*a(n) = (n^6-1)/(n^2-1) = n^4 + n^2 + 1 = a(n^2+1) (a product of two consecutive numbers from this sequence belongs to this sequence). (a(n+1) + a(n))/2 = n^2 + 1. (a(n+1) - a(n))/2 = n. a((a(n+1) + a(n))/2) = a(n+1)*a(n). - _Alexander Adamchuk_, Apr 13 2006
a(n+3) is the numerator of ((n + 1)! + (n - 1)!)/ n!. - _Artur Jasinski_, Jan 09 2007
a(n) = A132111(n-1, 1), for n > 1. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Aug 10 2007
a(n) = 3*a(n-1) - 3*a(n-2) + a(n-3), n >= 3. - _Jaume Oliver Lafont_, Dec 02 2008
a(n) = A176271(n,1) for n > 0. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Apr 13 2010
a(n) = (n-1)^2 + (n-1) + 1 = 111 read in base n-1 (for n > 2). - _Jason Kimberley_, Oct 18 2011
a(n) = A228643(n, 1), for n > 0. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Aug 29 2013
For n >= 2, a(n) = ceiling(4/(Sum_{k = A000217(n-1)..A000217(n) - 1}, 1/k)). - _Richard R. Forberg_, Aug 17 2014
For n > 1, sqrt(a(n)+sqrt(a(n)-sqrt(a(n)+sqrt(a(n)- ...)))) = n. - _Diego Rattaggi_, Apr 17 2021

A002062.name: a(n) = Fibonacci(n) + n.
formula: G.f.: x*(-2+3*x) ) / ( (x^2+x-1)*(x-1)^2 ). - _Simon Plouffe_ in his 1992 dissertation
Convolution of natural numbers n >= 1 with Fibonacci numbers F(k), k >= -3, (F(-k)=(-1)^(k+1)*F(k));

A002064.name: Cullen numbers: a(n) = n*2^n + 1.
formula: a(n) = sum of row (n+1) of triangle A130197. Example: a(3) = 25 = (12 + 8 + 4 + 1), row 4 of A130197. - _Gary W. Adamson_, May 16 2007
Row sums of triangle A134081. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Oct 07 2007
Equals row sums of triangle A143038. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Jul 18 2008
Equals row sums of triangle A156708. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Feb 13 2009
a(n) = 2^n * A000325(n) = 4^n * A186947(-n) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Jul 18 2018
a(n) = Sum_{i=0..n-1} a(i) + A000325(n+1). - _Ivan N. Ianakiev_, Aug 07 2019

A002067.name: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n-1} binomial(2*n,2*k)*a(k)*a(n-k-1).
formula: a(n) = b(2n+1), where e.g.f. of b satisfies B'(x)=exp(B(x)^2/2).
a(n) = 1/2^n * A026944(n+1). Let D denote the operator g(x) -> 1/sqrt(2)*d/dx(exp(x^2)*g(x)). Then a(n) = D^(2*n)(1) evaluated at x = 0. - _Peter Bala_, Sep 08 2011
E.g.f. B(x)=Sum_{n=1..inf} a(n-1)*x^(2*n)/(2*n)! satisfies differential equation B''(x) - B(x)*B''(x) - 1 = 0, B'(0)=1/2. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Aug 12 2019
E.g.f. satisfies: A(x) = exp( Integral A(x) * Integral A(x) dx dx ), where A(x) = Sum_{n>=0} a(n)*x^(2*n)/(2*n)! and the constant of integration is zero. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Jun 02 2015

A002068.name: Wilson remainders: a(n) = ((p-1)!+1)/p mod p, where p = prime(n).
formula: a(n) + A197631(n) = A275741(n) for n > 1. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Jul 08 2019
a(n) = ( A027641(p-1)/A027642(p-1) + 1/p - 1 ) mod p, where p = prime(n), proved by Glashier (1900). - _Max Alekseyev_, Jun 20 2020

A002070.name: Coefficient of x^p (p = n-th prime) in x * Product_{k>=1} (1-x^k)^2*(1-x^11k)^2.
formula: a(n) == 1 + prime(n) (mod 5) if prime(n) != 11. - _Seiichi Manyama_, Sep 17 2016

A002071.name: Number of pairs of consecutive integers x, x+1 such that all prime factors of both x and x+1 are at most the n-th prime.
formula: a(n) <= (2^n-1)*(prime(n)+1)/2 is implicit in Lehmer 1964. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Feb 19 2013

A002072.name: a(n) = smallest number m such that for all k > m, either k or k+1 has a prime factor > prime(n).
formula: a(n) < 10^n/n except for n=4. (Conjectured, from experimental data.) - _M. F. Hasler_, Jan 16 2015

A002073.name: Numerators of coefficients in an asymptotic expansion of the confluent hypergeometric function F(1-b; 2; 4b).
formula: Let f(x) = [Sum_{k>=1}(3/(2*k+1)) * x^(2*k+1)]^(1/3) = x + (1/5)*x^3 + (18/175) * x^5 + ...; let g(x) be the Lagrange inversion of f(x), g(x) = REVERT(f(x)) = 1 - (1/5) * x^3 + (3/175) * x^5 + .... Then a(n) = numerator((2 * n + 1) * coeff(g(x), 2*n+1)). - _Sean A. Irvine_, Jun 20 2013

A002074.name: Denominators of coefficients in an asymptotic expansion of the confluent hypergeometric function F(1-b; 2; 4b).
formula: Let f(x) = [Sum_{k>=1}(3/(2*k+1)) * x^(2*k+1)]^(1/3) = x + (1/5)*x^3 + (18/175) * x^5 + ...; let g(x) be the Lagrange inversion of f(x), g(x) = REVERT(f(x)) = 1 - (1/5) * x^3 + (3/175) * x^5 + .... Then a(n) = denominator((2 * n + 1) * coeff(g(x), 2*n+1)). - _Sean A. Irvine_, Jun 20 2013

A002075.name: Number of equivalence classes with primitive period n of base 3 necklaces, where necklaces are equivalent under rotation and permutation of symbols.
formula: Sequence A002076 can be found as foolows: Let F3(n) = this sequence, F3*(n) = function from A002076. Then F3*(n) = Sum_{ d divides n } F3(d).

A002076.name: Number of equivalence classes of base-3 necklaces of length n, where necklaces are considered equivalent under both rotations and permutations of the symbols.

A002077.name: Number of self-dual threshold functions of n variables.

A002078.name: N-equivalence classes of threshold functions of n or fewer variables.

A002079.name: N-equivalence classes of threshold gates of exactly n variables.

A002080.name: Number of self-dual functions of n variables.

A002081.name: Numbers congruent to {2, 4, 8, 16} mod 20.
formula: a(n + 4) = a(n) + 20 for n > 3. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Sep 15 2011

A002083.name: Narayana-Zidek-Capell numbers: a(2n) = 2a(2n-1), a(2n+1) = 2a(2n) - a(n).
formula: a(1)=1, else a(n) is sum of floor(n/2) previous terms.
Conjecture: lim_{n->inf} a(n)/2^(n-3) = a constant ~ 0.633368 - _Gerald McGarvey_, Jul 18 2004
First column of A155092. - _Mats Granvik_, Jan 20 2009

Limit is equal to 0.633368347305411640436713144616576659... = 2* Atkinson-Negro-Santoro constant, see Finch's book, chapter 2.28 (Erdős' Sum-Distinct Set Constant), pp. 189, 552. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Nov 19 2012
a(n) is the permanent of the (n-1) X (n-1) matrix with (i, j) entry = 1 if i-1 <= j <= 2*i-1 and = 0 otherwise. - _David Callan_, Nov 02 2005

a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} K(n-k+1, k)*a(n-k), where K(n,k) = 1 if 0 <= k AND k <= n and K(n,k)=0 else. (Several arguments to the K-coefficient K(n,k) can lead to the same sequence. For example, we get A002083 also from a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} K((n-k)!,k!)*a(n-k), where K(n,k) = 1 if 0 <= k <= n and 0 else. See also the comment to a similar formula for A002487.) - _Thomas Wieder_, Jan 13 2008
G.f. satisfies: A(x) = (1-x - x^2*A(x^2))/(1-2x). - _Paul D. Hanna_, Mar 17 2010

A002084.name: Sinh x / cos x = Sum_{n>=0} a(n)*x^(2n+1)/(2n+1)!.

A002085.name: From the expansion of sinh x / cos x: a(n) = odd part of A002084(n).

A002086.name: Number of circulant tournaments on 2n+1 nodes up to Cayley isomorphism.

A002087.name: Number of point-symmetric tournaments with 2n+1 nodes.

A002088.name: Sum of totient function: a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} phi(k), cf. A000010.
formula: More precisely, a(n) = (3/Pi^2)*n^2 + O(n*(log(n))^(2/3)*(log(log(n)))^(4/3)), (A. Walfisz 1963). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Feb 02 2003
A slightly simpler version of Cloitre's formula is a(n) = 1/2 + Sum_{k=1..oo} floor(n/k)^2*mu(k)/2. - _Bill Gosper_, Jul 25 2020
The quotient A024916(n)/a(n) = SummatorySigma/SummatoryTotient as n increases seems to approach (Pi^4)/36 = Zeta(2)^2 = 2.705808084277845. See also A067282. - _Labos Elemer_, Sep 21 2004
A024916(n)/a(n) = zeta(2)^2 + O(log(n)/n). This follows from asymptotic formulas for the sequences. - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Oct 19 2006
Row sums of triangle A134542. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Oct 31 2007
G.f.: (Sum_{n>=1} mu(n)*x^n/(1-x^n)^2)/(1-x), where mu(n) = A008683(n). - _Mamuka Jibladze_, Apr 06 2015
a(n) = A005728(n) - 1, for n >= 0. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Nov 22 2016

a(n) = (Sum_{k=1..floor(sqrt(n))} k*(k+1) * (M(floor(n/k)) - M(floor(n/(k+1)))) + Sum_{k=1..floor(n/(1+floor(sqrt(n))))} mu(k) * floor(n/k) * floor(1+n/k))/2, where M(k) is the Mertens function (A002321) and mu(k) is the Moebius function (A008683). - _Daniel Suteu_, Nov 23 2018

A002091.name: From a Goldbach conjecture: the location of records in A185091.

A002092.name: From a Goldbach conjecture: records in A185091.

A002093.name: Highly abundant numbers: numbers k such that sigma(k) > sigma(m) for all m < k.

A002094.name: Number of unlabeled connected loop-less graphs on n nodes containing exactly one cycle (of length at least 2) and with all nodes of degree <= 4.
formula: Let A(x) denote the generating function for A000598 (Number of rooted ternary trees with n nodes), i.e., A(x) = 1+(1/6)*x*(A(x)^3+3*A(x)*A(x^2)+2*A(x^3)), and set B(x)=(A(x)^2+A(x^2))/2. With D_k(x) being the cycle polynomial of the regular k-gon for k>=2, the final generating function is then given by Sum_{k>=2} x^k*D_k(B(x)), which can be evaluated very quickly. - _Sascha Kurz_, Mar 18 2018

A002095.name: Number of partitions of n into nonprime parts.

A002097.name: Numbers that are not the sum of 3 nonzero triangular numbers.

A002100.name: a(n) = number of partitions of n into semiprimes (more precisely, number of ways of writing n as a sum of products of 2 distinct primes).

A002102.name: Number of nonnegative solutions to x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = n.
formula: Coefficient of q^k in 1/8*(1 + theta_3(0, q))^3, or coefficient of q^n in (1+q+q^4+q^9+q^16+q^25+q^36+q^49+q^64+...)^3.

A002103.name: Coefficients of expansion of Jacobi nome q in certain powers of (1/2)*(1 - sqrt(k')) / (1 + sqrt(k')).
formula: a(n) = Sum {1<=k<=n} (-1)^k Sum { (4n+k)! C_1^b_1 ... C_n^b_n / (4n+1)! b_1! ... b_n! }, where the inner sum is over all partitions k = b_1 + ... + b_n, n = Sum i*b_i, b_i >= 0 and C_0=1, C_1=-2, C_2=5, C_3=-10 ... is given by (-1)^n*A001936(n).
G.f.: Series_Reversion( (theta_3(x) - theta_3(-x)) / (4*theta_3(x^4)) ) = Sum_{n>=0} a(n)*x^(4*n+1), where theta_3(x) = 1 + 2*Sum_{n>=1} x^(n^2). - _Paul D. Hanna_, Jan 07 2014

A002104.name: Logarithmic numbers.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} n(n-1)...(n-k+1)/k = A006231(n) + n - Avi Peretz (njk(AT)netvision.net.il), Mar 24 2001
a(n) = sum{k=0..n-1, binomial(n, k)*(n-k-1)!}, row sums of A111492. - _Paul Barry_, Aug 26 2004
a(n) = Sum[Sum[m!/k!,{k,0,m}],{m,0,n-1}]. a(n) = Sum[A000522(m),{m,0,n-1}]. - _Alexander Adamchuk_, Jul 05 2006
For n > 1, the arithmetic mean of the first n terms is a(n-1) + 1. - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, May 20 2010
The generating series A(x) = -exp(x)*log(1-x) satisfies the differential equations:
From the first one, we have the recurrence reported below by R. R. Forberg. From the second one, we have the recurrence conjectured above. (End)
G.f.: conjecture: T(0)*x/(1-2*x)/(1-x), where T(k) = 1 - x^2*(k+1)^2/(x^2*(k+1)^2 - (1 - 2*x*(k+1))*(1 - 2*x*(k+2))/T(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Nov 18 2013

A002105.name: Reduced tangent numbers: 2^n*(2^{2n} - 1)*|B_{2n}|/n, where B_n = Bernoulli numbers.
formula: E.g.f.: 2*log(sec(x / sqrt(2))) = Sum_{n>0} a(n) * x^(2*n) / (2*n)!. - _Michael Somos_, Jun 22 2002
a(n+1) = Sum_{k =0..n} A094665(n, k). - _Philippe Deléham_, Jun 11 2004
sqrt(2) tan( x/sqrt(2)) = Sum_(n>=0) (x^(2n+1)/(2n+1)!) a_n. - Dominique Foata and Guo-Niu Han, Oct 24 2008

Basic hypergeometric generating function: Sum_{n>=0} Product {k = 1..n} (1-exp(-2*k*t))/Product {k = 1..n} (1+exp(-2*k*t)) = 1 + t + 4*t^2/2! + 34*t^3/3! + 496*t^4/4! + ... [Andrews et al., Theorem 4]. For other sequences with generating functions of a similar type see A000364, A000464, A002439, A079144 and A158690. - _Peter Bala_, Mar 24 2009
E.g.f.: Sum_{n>=0} Product_{k=1..n} tanh(k*x) = Sum_{n>=0} a(n)*x^n/n!. - _Paul D. Hanna_, May 11 2010
a(n) = upper left term in M^n, a(n+1) = sum of top row terms in M^n; where M = the infinite square production matrix:
E.g.f. A(x) satisfies differential equation A''(x)=exp(A(x)). - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Nov 18 2011
E.g.f.: For E(x)=sqrt(2)* tan( x/sqrt(2))=x/G(0); G(k)= 4*k + 1 - x^2/(8*k + 6 - x^2/G(k+1)); (from continued fraction Lambert's, 2-step). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jan 14 2012
a(n) = (-1)^n*2^(n+1)*Li_{1-2*n}(-1). (See also the Mathematica prog. by Vladimir Reshetnikov.) - _Peter Luschny_, Jun 28 2012
G.f.: 1/G(0) where G(k) = 1 - x*( 4*k^2 + 4*k + 1 ) - x^2*(k+1)^2*( 4*k^2 + 8*k + 3)/G(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jan 14 2013
G.f.: 1/Q(0), where Q(k) = 1 - (k+1)*(k+2)/2*x/Q(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, May 03 2013

G.f.: (1/G(0))/sqrt(x) - 1/sqrt(x), where G(k) = 1 - sqrt(x)*(2*k+1)/(1 + sqrt(x)*(2*k+1)/(1 + sqrt(x)*(k+1)/(1 - sqrt(x)*(k+1)/G(k+1) ))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jul 07 2013
G.f.: T(0), where T(k) = 1-x*(k+1)*(k+2)/(x*(k+1)*(k+2)-2/T(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Oct 24 2013

The e.g.f. A(x) = sqrt(2)*tan(x/sqrt(2)) satisfies A''(x) = A(x)*A'(x), hence the recurrence a(0) = 0, a(1) = 1, else a(n) = Sum_{i = 0..n-2} binomial(n-2,i)*a(i)*a(n-1-i) for the aerated sequence [0,1,0,1,0,4,0,34,0,496,...].
Note, the same recurrence, but with the initial conditions a(0) = 1 and a(1) = 1, produces the sequence [1,1,1,2,5,16,61,272,...] = A000111. (End)
E.g.f.: sqrt(2)*tan(x/sqrt(2)) = Sum_{n>0} a(n) * x^(2*n-1) / (2*n-1)!. - _Michael Somos_, Mar 05 2017

Let B(x) = A(x)/x = 1 + x + 4*x^2 + 34*x^3 + ... denote the shifted o.g.f. Then B(x) = 1/(1 + 2*x - 3*x/(1 - x/(1 + 2*x - 10*x/(1 - 6*x/(1 + 2*x - 21*x/(1 - 15*x/(1 + 2*x - 36*x/(1 - 28*x/(1 + 2*x - ...))))))))), where the coefficient sequence [3, 1, 10, 6, 21, 15, 36, 28, ...] in the partial numerators of the continued fraction is obtained by swapping adjacent triangular numbers. Cf. A079144.

It follows (by means of an equivalence transformation) that the second binomial transform of B(x), with g.f. equal to 1/(1 - 2*x)*B(x/(1 - 2*x)), has the S-fraction representation 1/(1 - 3*x/(1 - x/(1 - 10*x/(1 - 6*x/(1 - 21*x/(1 - 15*x/(1 - 36*x/(1 - 28*x/(1 - ...))))))))). Compare with the S-fraction representation of the g.f. A(x) given above by Hanna (dated Oct 7 2005). (End)

A002106.name: Number of transitive permutation groups of degree n.

A002107.name: Expansion of Product_{k>=1} (1 - x^k)^2.
formula: Expansion of q^(-1/12) * eta(q)^2 in powers of q. - _Michael Somos_, Mar 06 2012
Euler transform of period 1 sequence [ -2, ...]. - _Michael Somos_, Mar 06 2012

a(n) = b(12*n + 1) where b(n) is multiplicative and b(2^e) = b(3^e) = 0^e, b(p^e) = (1 + (-1)^e) / 2 if p == 7, 11 (mod 12), b(p^e) = (-1)^(e/2) * (1 + (-1)^e) / 2 if p == 5 (mod 12), b(p^e) = (e + 1) * (-1)^(e*x) if p == 1 (mod 12) where p = x^2 + 9*y^2. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 16 2006
Expansion of f(-x)^2 in powers of x where f() is a Ramanujan theta function. - _Michael Somos_, May 17 2015
G.f. is a period 1 Fourier series which satisfies f(-1 / (144 t)) = 12 (t/i) f(t) where q = exp(2 Pi i t). - _Michael Somos_, May 17 2015
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} A010815(k)*A010815(n-k); self convolution of A010815. - _Gevorg Hmayakyan_, Sep 18 2016
G.f.: exp(-2*Sum_{k>=1} x^k/(k*(1 - x^k))). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Feb 05 2018
For prime p congruent to 5, 7 or 11 (mod 12), a(n*p^2 + (p^2 - 1)/12) = e*a(n), where e = 1 if p == 7 or 11 (mod 12) and e = -1 if p == 5 (mod 12).
If n and p are coprime then a(n*p + (p^2 - 1)/12) = 0. See Cooper et al., Theorem 1. (End)

A002108.name: 4th powers written backwards.
formula: a(n * 10^k) = a(n) for k >= 1. - _Bernard Schott_, Jun 04 2019

A002109.name: Hyperfactorials: Product_{k = 1..n} k^k.
formula: Determinant of n X n matrix m(i, j) = binomial(i*j, i). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Aug 27 2003
a(n) = exp(zeta'(-1, n + 1) - zeta'(-1)) where zeta(s, z) is the Hurwitz zeta function. - _Peter Luschny_, Jun 23 2012
G.f.: 1 = Sum_{n>=0} a(n)*x^n / Product_{k=1..n+1} (1 + k^k*x). - _Paul D. Hanna_, Oct 02 2013
a(n) ~ A * n^(n*(n+1)/2 + 1/12) / exp(n^2/4), where A = 1.2824271291006226368753425... is the Glaisher-Kinkelin constant (see A074962). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Feb 20 2015
a(n) = Product_{k=1..n} ff(n,k) where ff denotes the falling factorial. - _Peter Luschny_, Nov 29 2015
log a(n) = (1/2) n^2 log n - (1/4) n^2 + (1/2) n log n + (1/12) log n + log(A) + o(1), where log(A) = A225746 is the logarithm of Glaisher's constant. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Mar 27 2020

A002110.name: Primorial numbers (first definition): product of first n primes. Sometimes written prime(n)#.
formula: Asymptotic expression for a(n): exp((1 + o(1)) * n * log(n)) where o(1) is the "little o" notation. - Dan Fux (dan.fux(AT)OpenGaia.com or danfux(AT)OpenGaia.com), Apr 08 2001
Binomial transform = A136104: (1, 3, 11, 55, 375, 3731, ...). Equals binomial transform of A121572: (1, 1, 3, 17, 119, 1509, ...). - _Gary W. Adamson_, Dec 14 2007
a(n) = Product_{i=1..n} A000040(i). - _Jonathan Vos Post_, Jul 17 2008
a(n) = A035345(n) - A005235(n) for n > 0. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Dec 02 2015
a(n) = A270592(2*n+2) - A270592(2*n+1) if 0 <= n <= 4 (conjectured for all n by _Alon Kellner_). - _Jonathan Sondow_, Mar 25 2018

A002111.name: Glaisher's G numbers.
formula: To get these numbers, expand the e.g.f. (3/2)/(1+exp(x)+exp(-x)), multiply coefficient of x^n by (n+1)! and take absolute values.
Or expand the e.g.f. (3/2)/(1+2*cos(x)) and multiply coefficient of x^n by (n+1)!. - _Herb Conn_, Feb 25 2002
a(n) = (2n+1)*I(n), where I(n) is given by A047788/A047789.
a(n) = sum(i=0, 2n, B(i)*C(2n+1, i)*3^i) where B(i) are the Bernoulli numbers, C(2n, i) the binomial numbers. - _Benoit Cloitre_, May 01 2002
a(n) = (-1)^n * (6*n + 3) * s(2*n), if n>0, where s(n) are the cubic Bernoulli numbers. - _Michael Somos_, Feb 26 2004

E.g.f.: E(x)=(3/2)/(1+2*cos(x))-1/2 = x^2/(3*G(0)+x^2) ; G(k)= 2*(2*k+1)*(k+1) - x^2 + 2*x^2*(2*k+1)*(k+1)/G(k+1); (continued fraction Euler's kind, 1-step). Let f[n]:=coeftayl(E(x), x=0, n) then: A002111[n]=f[2*n+2]*((2*n+3)!). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jan 14 2012
a(n) = sum_{k=0..2n+1} sum_{j=0..k} sum_{v=0..j} ((-1)^(n-v+1)/(j+1))* binomial(2*n+1,k)*binomial(j,v)*(3*v)^k. - _Peter Luschny_, Jun 03 2013
a(n) = (-1)^(n+1)*3^(2*n+1)*B(2*n+1,1/3), where B(n,x) denotes the n-th Bernoulli polynomial. Cf. A009843, A069852, A069994.
Conjecturally, a(n) = the unsigned numerator of B(2*n+1,1/3). Cf. A033470.

A002112.name: Glaisher's H numbers.
formula: E.g.f.: E(x)= 3*x^2/(G(0)-x^2) ; G(k)= 2*(2*k+1)*(k+1) - x^2 + 2*x^2*(2*k+1)*(k+1)/G(k+1); (continued fraction Euler's kind, 1-step ).- _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jan 03 2012
If E(x) = Sum(k=0,1,..., a(k+1)*x^(2k+2 )), then A002112(k) = a(k+1)*(2*k+2)!. - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jan 09 2012

A002114.name: Glaisher's H' numbers.
formula: E.g.f.: E(x)= x^2/(G(0)-x^2) ; G(k)= 2*(2*k+1)*(k+1) - x^2 + 2*x^2*(2*k+1)*(k+1)/G(k+1); (continued fraction Euler's kind, 1-step ). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jan 03 2012
If E(x)=Sum(k=0,1,..., a(k+1)*x^(2k+2)), then A002114(k) = a(k+1)*(2*k+2)!. - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jan 09 2012
a(n) = (-1)^n*6^(2*n)*(zeta(-n*2,1/3)-zeta(-n*2,5/6)), where zeta(a, z) is the generalized Riemann zeta function.

A002115.name: Generalized Euler numbers.
formula: Alternating row sums of A278073. - _Peter Luschny_, Sep 07 2017
a(0) = 1; a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} (-1)^(k+1) * binomial(3*n,3*k) * a(n-k). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Jan 27 2020

A002117.name: Decimal expansion of zeta(3) = Sum_{m >= 1} 1/m^3.
formula: Lima gives an approximation to zeta(3) as (236*log(2)^3)/197 - 283/394*Pi*log(2)^2 + 11/394*Pi^2*log(2) + 209/394*log(sqrt(2) + 1)^3 - 5/197 + (93*Catalan*Pi)/197. - _Jonathan Vos Post_, Oct 14 2009 [Corrected by _Wouter Meeussen_, Apr 04 2010]

zeta(3) = -4/3*Integral_{x=0..1} log(x)/x*log(1+x) = Integral_{x=0..1} log(x)/x*log(1-x) = -4/7*Integral_{x=0..1} log(x)/x*log((1+x)/(1-x)) = 4*Integral_{x=0..1} 1/x*log(1+x)^2 = 1/2*Integral_{x=0..1} 1/x*log(1-x)^2 = -16/7*Integral_{x=0..Pi/2} x*log(2*cos(x)) = -4/Pi*Integral_{x=0..Pi/2} x^2*log(2*cos(x)). - _Jean-François Alcover_, Apr 02 2013, after _R. J. Mathar_
More generally, there is a sequence of polynomials P(n,x) (of degree 2*n) such that
zeta(3) = Sum_{n >= 1} (A010052(n)/n^(3/2)) = Sum_{n >= 1} ( (floor(sqrt(n)) - floor(sqrt(n-1)))/n^(3/2) ). - _Mikael Aaltonen_, Feb 22 2015
zeta(3) = Sum_{k>=1} H(k)/(k+1)^2, where H(k) = A001008(k)/A002805(k) is the k-th harmonic number. - _Amiram Eldar_, Jul 31 2020
zeta(3) = (8/7)*Li_3(1/2) + (2/21)*Pi^2 log(2) - (4/21) log(2)^3, where f is golden ratio (A001622) and Li_3 is the polylogarithm function, formulas published by John Landen in 1780, p. 118. (End)

A002119.name: Bessel polynomial y_n(-2).
formula: D-finite with recurrence a(n) = -2(2n-1)*a(n-1) + a(n-2). - _T. D. Noe_, Oct 26 2006
If y = x + Sum_{k>=2} A005363(k)*x^k/k!, then y = x + Sum{k>=2} a(k-2)(-y)^k/k!. - _Michael Somos_, Apr 02 2007
G.f.: 1/Q(0), where Q(k)= 1 - x + 2*x*(k+1)/Q(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, May 17 2013
a(n) = sqrt(Pi/exp(1)) * BesselI(1/2+n, 1/2) + (-1)^n * BesselK(1/2+n, 1/2) / sqrt(exp(1)*Pi). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jul 22 2015

A002120.name: a(1) = 0, a(2) = -2; for n > 2, a(n) + a(n-2) - a(n-3) - a(n-5) - ... - a(n-p) = (-1)^(n+1)*n if n is prime, otherwise = 0, where p = largest prime < n.

A002121.name: a(0) = 1, a(1) = 0, a(2) = -1; for n >= 3, a(n) = - a(n-2) + Sum_{ primes p with 3 <= p <= n} a(n-p).

A002122.name: a(n) = Sum_{t=0..n} g(t)*g(n-t) where g(t) = A002121(t).

A002123.name: a(1) = 0, a(2) = 0; for n > 2, a(n) - a(n-3) - a(n-5) - ... - a(n-p) = n if n is prime, otherwise = 0, where p = largest prime < n.

A002124.name: Number of compositions of n into a sum of odd primes.
formula: a(0)=1, a(1)=a(2)=0; for n >= 3, a(n) = Sum_{ primes p with 3 <= p <= n} a(n-p). [MacMahon]

A002125.name: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} f(k)*f(n-k) where f(k) = A002124(k).

A002126.name: Number of solutions to n=p+q where p and q are primes or zero.
formula: G.f.: (1 + Sum_i x^prime(i))^2. [Corrected by _T. D. Noe_, Dec 05 2006]

A002127.name: MacMahon's generalized sum of divisors function.

A002128.name: MacMahon's generalized sum of divisors function.

A002129.name: Generalized sum of divisors function: excess of sum of odd divisors of n over sum of even divisors of n.
formula: Multiplicative with a(p^e) = 3-2^(e+1) if p = 2; (p^(e+1)-1)/(p-1) if p > 2. - _David W. Wilson_, Sep 01 2001
L.g.f.: Sum_{n>=1} a(n)*x^n/n = log[ Sum_{n>=0} x^(n(n+1)/2) ], the log of the g.f. of A010054. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Jun 28 2008
Dirichlet g.f. zeta(s)*zeta(s-1)*(1-4/2^s). Dirichlet convolution of A000203 and the quasi-finite (1,-4,0,0,0,...). - _R. J. Mathar_, Mar 04 2011

A002130.name: Generalized sum of divisors function.
formula: G.f.: (t(1)^2-t(2))/2 where t(i) = Sum(x^(n*i)/(1+x^n)^(2*i),n=1..inf), i=1..2. - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Sep 21 2007

A002131.name: Sum of divisors d of n such that n/d is odd.
formula: Expansion of K(k^2) * (K(k^2) - E(k^2)) / (2 * Pi^2) in powers of q where q is Jacobi's nome and K(), E() are complete elliptic integrals. - _Michael Somos_, Aug 01 2011
Multiplicative with a(p^e) = p^e if p = 2; (p^(e+1)-1)/(p-1) if p > 2. - _David W. Wilson_, Aug 01 2001
a(n) = sigma(n) - sigma(n/2) for even n and = sigma(n) otherwise where sigma(n) is the sum of divisors of n (A000203). - _Valery A. Liskovets_, Apr 07 2002
G.f.: A(x) satisfies 0 = f(A(x), A(x^2), A(x^3), A(x^6)) where f(u1, u2, u3, u6) = 2*u1*u6 - u1*u3 - 10*u2*u6 + u2^2 + 2*u2*u3 + 9*u6^2. - _Michael Somos_, Apr 10 2005
G.f.: A(x) satisfies 0 = f(A(x), A(x^2), A(x^3), A(x^6)) where f(u1, u2, u3, u6) = (u2 - 3*u6)^2 - (u1 - 2*u2) * (u3 - 2*u6). - _Michael Somos_, Sep 06 2005
G.f.: (1/8) * theta_4''(0) / theta_4(0) = (Sum_{k>0} -(-1)^k * k^2 q^(k^2)) / (Sum_{k in Z} (-1)^k * q^(k^2)) where theta_4(u) is one of Jacobi's theta functions.
G.f.: A(q) = Z'(0) * K^2 / (2 * Pi^2) = (K - E) * K /(2 * Pi^2) where Z(u) is the Jacobi Zeta function and K, E are complete elliptic integrals. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 06 2005
Dirichlet g.f.: zeta(s) * zeta(s-1) * (1 - 1/2^s). - _Michael Somos_, Apr 05 2003

a(n) = n * Sum_{c|n} 1/c, where c are odd numbers (A005408) dividing n. a(n) = A069359(n) + n. a(n) = A000035(n) (*) A000027(n), where operation (*) denotes Dirichlet convolution, that is, convolution of type: a(n) = Sum_{d|n} b(d) * c(n/d) = Sum_{d|n} A000035(d) * A000027(n/d). -_Jaroslav Krizek_, Nov 07 2013
L.g.f.: Sum_{ k>0 } atanh(x^k) = Sum_{ n>0 } (a(n)/n)*x^n. - _Benedict W. J. Irwin_, Jul 05 2016
Sum_{k=1..n} a(k) ~ Pi^2 * n^2 /16. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Feb 01 2019

A002133.name: Number of partitions of n with exactly two part sizes.
formula: G.f.: Sum_{i>=1} Sum_{j=1..i-1} x^(i+j)/((1-x^i)*(1-x^j)). - _Emeric Deutsch_, Mar 30 2006
Andrews gives a formula which is programmed up in the Maple code below. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Jun 17 2011

G.f.: (G(x)^2-H(x))/2 where G(x) = Sum_{k>0} x^k/(1-x^k) and H(x) = Sum_{k>0} x^(2*k)/(1-x^k)^2. More generally, we obtain g.f. for number of partitions of n with m types of parts if we substitute x(i) with -Sum_{k>0}(x^n/(x^n-1))^i in cycle index Z(S(m); x(1),x(2),...,x(m)) of symmetric group S(m) of degree m. - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Sep 18 2007

A002134.name: Generalized divisor function. Partitions of n using only 3 types of piles.
formula: G.f.: Sum_{i>=1} Sum_{j=1..i-1} Sum_{k=1..j-1} x^(i+j+k)/((1-x^i)*(1-x^j)* (1-x^k)). - _Geoffrey Critzer_, Sep 13 2012

A002135.name: Number of terms in a symmetrical determinant: a(n) = n*a(n-1) - (n-1)*(n-2)*a(n-3)/2.
formula: D-finite with recurrence a(n+1) = (n+1)*a(n) - binomial(n, 2)*a(n-2). See Comtet.
E.g.f.: G(0)/sqrt(1-x) where G(k) = 1 + x*(x+2)/(4*(2*k+1) - 4*x*(x+2)*(2*k+1)/(x*(x+2) + 8*(k + 1)/G(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jan 31 2013

A002137.name: Number of n X n symmetric matrices with nonnegative integer entries, trace 0 and all row sums 2.
formula: a(n) ~ sqrt(2) * n^n / exp(n+1/4). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Feb 25 2014

A002139.name: Shuffling 2n cards.
formula: a(n) = (f(n)+1) * phi(p^(k-1)) if 2 is primitive mod 2n-1 in which case necessarily 2n-1=p^k, p prime; otherwise, a(n) = lcm(f(n), f(n)+1), where f(n) = A002326(n-1). - _Sean A. Irvine_, Jul 17 2013

A002142.name: Primes p == 1 (mod 4) where class number of Q(sqrt p) increases.

A002143.name: Class numbers h(-p) where p runs through the primes p == 3 (mod 4).
formula: h(-p) = 1 + 2*sum(0 <= n <= (1/2)*sqrt(p/3)-1, d(n^2+n+(p+1)/4, [2*n+1, sqrt(n^2+n+(p+1)/4)])) for prime p=3 mod 4, p>3. d(n, [a, b])=card{d: d|n and a<d<b} for integer n and real a, b. - Antonio G. Astudillo (afg_astudillo(AT)hotmail.com), Jul 19 2002
h(-p) = -(1/p)*sum(n=1..p-1, n*(n|p)) if p > 3, where (n|p) = +/- 1 is the Legendre symbol. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Oct 27 2011
h(-p) = (1/3)*sum(n=1..(p-1)/2, (n|p)) or sum(n=1..(p-1)/2, (n|p)) according as p == 3 or 7 (mod 8). - _Jonathan Sondow_, Feb 27 2012

A002144.name: Pythagorean primes: primes of form 4*k + 1.
formula: Odd primes of form x^2 + y^2, (x=A002331, y=A002330, with x < y) or of form u^2 + 4*v^2, (u = A002972, v = A002973, with u odd). - _Lekraj Beedassy_, Jul 16 2004
a(n) = (A002972(n)^2 + (2*A002973(n))^2, n >= 1. See the _Jean-Christophe Hervé_ Nov 11 2013 comment. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Jan 13 2015

Sum_{k >= 1} 1/a(k)^s = (1/2) * Sum_{n >= 1 odd numbers} moebius(n) * log((2*n*s)! * zeta(n*s) * abs(EulerE(n*s - 1)) / (Pi^(n*s) * 2^(2*n*s) * BernoulliB(2*n*s) * (2^(n*s) + 1) * (n*s - 1)!))/n, s >= 3 odd number. - _Dimitris Valianatos_, May 21 2020
Legendre symbol (-1, a(n)) = +1, for n >= 1. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Mar 03 2021

A002145.name: Primes of the form 4*k+3.
formula: Remove from A000040 terms that are in A002313.
Intersection of A000040 and A004767. - _Alonso del Arte_, Apr 22 2014

Sum_{k >= 1} 1/a(k)^s = (1/2) * Sum_{n >= 1 odd numbers} moebius(n) * log(2 * (2^(n*s) - 1) * (n*s - 1)! * zeta(n*s) / (Pi^(n*s) * abs(EulerE(n*s - 1))))/n, s >= 3 odd number. - _Dimitris Valianatos_, May 20 2020

A002146.name: Smallest prime == 7 mod 8 where Q(sqrt -p) has class number 2n+1.

A002147.name: Largest prime == 7 mod 8 with class number 2n+1.

A002148.name: Smallest prime p==3 (mod 8) such that Q(sqrt(-p)) has class number 2n+1.

A002149.name: Largest prime p==3 (mod 8) such that Q(sqrt(-p)) has class number 2n+1.

A002150.name: Numbers n for which rank of the elliptic curve y^2=x^3-n is 0.

A002151.name: Numbers k for which rank of the elliptic curve y^2 = x^3 + k is 0.

A002152.name: Numbers n for which rank of the elliptic curve y^2=x^3-n is 1.

A002153.name: Numbers n for which rank of the elliptic curve y^2=x^3+n is 1.

A002154.name: Numbers n for which rank of the elliptic curve y^2=x^3-n is 2.

A002155.name: Numbers n for which rank of the elliptic curve y^2=x^3+n is 2.

A002156.name: Numbers k for which rank of the elliptic curve y^2 = x^3 - k*x is 0.

A002157.name: Numbers k for which rank of the elliptic curve y^2=x^3-k*x is 1.

A002158.name: Numbers k for which rank of the elliptic curve y^2 = x^3 + k*x is 0.

A002159.name: Numbers k for which rank of the elliptic curve y^2=x^3+k*x is 1.

A002161.name: Decimal expansion of square root of Pi.

A002162.name: Decimal expansion of the natural logarithm of 2.
formula: From log(1-x-x^2) at x=1/2, log(2)=(1/2)*Sum_{k>=1} L(k)/(k*2^k), where L(n) is the n-th Lucas number (A000032). - _Jaume Oliver Lafont_, Oct 24 2009
log(2) = Sum_{k>=1} 1/(cos(k*Pi/3)*k*2^k) (Cf. A176900). - _Jaume Oliver Lafont_, Apr 29 2010
log(2) = Integral_{x=0..oo} 1/(1 + e^x) dx. - _Jean-François Alcover_, Mar 21 2013
log(2) = limit of zeta(s)*(1-1/2^(s-1)) as s -> 1. - _Mats Granvik_, Jun 18 2013
log(2) = 2*Sum_{n>=1} 1/( n*A008288(n-1,n-1)*A008288(n,n) ), a result due to Burnside.
See A142979 for series acceleration formulas for log(2) obtained from the Mercator series log(2) = Sum_{n >= 1} (-1)^(n+1)/n. See A142992 for series for log(2) related to the root lattice C_n. (End)
log(2) = Sum_{k=2^n..2^(n+1)-1} 1/k as n -> infinity. - _Richard R. Forberg_, Aug 16 2014

Define a pair of integer sequences A(n) = 9^n*(2*n + 1)!/n! and B(n) = A(n)*Sum_{k = 0..n} 1/((2*k + 1)*9^k). Both satisfy the same second order recurrence equation u(n) = (40*n + 16)*u(n-1) - 36*(2*n - 1)^2*u(n-2). From this observation we obtain the continued fraction expansion log(2) = 2/3*(1 + 2/(54 - 36*3^2/(96 - 36*5^2/(136 - ... - 36*(2*n - 1)^2/((40*n + 16) - ... ))))). Cf. A002391, A073000 and A105531 for similar expansions. (End)

for N even, log(2) - Sum_{k = 1..N/2} (-1)^(k-1)/k ~ (-1)^(N/2)*(1/N - 1/N^2 + 2/N^4 - 16/N^6 + 272/N^8 - ...), where the sequence of unsigned coefficients [1, 1, 2, 16, 272, ...] is A000182 with an extra initial term of 1. See Borwein et al., Theorem 1 (b);

for N odd, log(2) - Sum_{k = 1..(N-1)/2} (-1)^(k-1)/k ~ (-1)^((N-1)/2)*(1/N - 1/N^3 + 5/N^5 - 61/N^7 + 1385/N^9 - ...), by Borwein et al., Lemma 2 with f(x) := 1/(x + 1/2), h := 1/2 and then set x = (N - 1)/2, where the sequence of unsigned coefficients [1, 1, 5, 61, 1385, ...] is A000364. (End)
log(2) = limit_{n-> infinity} Sum_{k=1..n} sin(1/(n+k)). See Mathematical Reflections link. - _Michel Marcus_, Jan 07 2017
log(2) = Integral_{x=0..Pi/2} (sec(x) - tan(x)) dx. - _Clark Kimberling_, Jul 08 2020
log(2) = Integral_{x = 0..1} (x - 1)/log(x) dx (Boros and Moll, p. 97).

A002163.name: Decimal expansion of square root of 5.
formula: Equals -1 + 2*phi. with phi = A001622. An integer number in the real quadratic number field Q(sqrt(5)). - _Wolfdieter Lang_, May 09 2018

A002165.name: High temperature series for spin-1/2 Heisenberg specific heat on 3-dimensional f.c.c. lattice.

A002169.name: High temperature series for spin-1/2 Heisenberg specific heat on 3-dimensional simple cubic lattice.

A002170.name: High temperature series for spin-1/2 Heisenberg susceptibility on 3-dimensional simple cubic lattice.

A002171.name: Glaisher's chi numbers. a(n) = chi(4*n + 1).
formula: Expansion of (psi(x) * phi(-x))^2 = phi(-x) * f(-x^2)^3 in powers of x where phi(), psi(), f() are Ramanujan theta functions.
Expansion of q^(-1/4) * eta(q)^2 * eta(q^2)^2 in powers of q.

a(n) = b(4*n + 1) where b(n) is multiplicative with b(p^e) = b(p) * b(p^(e-1)) - p * b(p^(e-2)) and b(p) = p - number of solutions of y^2 = x^3 - x (mod p). - _Michael Somos_, Jul 27 2006. b(p(n)) = A278720(n). - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Dec 26 2016
Coefficients of L-series for elliptic curve "32a2": y^2 = x^3 - x.
G.f. is a period 1 Fourier series which satisfies f(-1 / (32 t)) = 32 (t/i)^2 f(t) where q = exp(2 Pi i t).

A002172.name: Glaisher's chi numbers chi(p) for p a prime of the form 4m+1.

A002173.name: a(n) = Sum_{d|n, d == 1 mod 4} d^2 - Sum_{d|n, d == 3 mod 4} d^2.
formula: Multiplicative with a(p^e) = 1 if p = 2; ((p^2)^(e+1)-1)/(p^2-1) if p == 1 (mod 4); ((-p^2)^(e+1)-1)/(-p^2-1) if p == 3 (mod 4). - _David W. Wilson_, Sep 01 2001 [This can be written as a single formula: a(p^e) = ((p^2*Chi(p))^(e+1) - 1)/(p^2*Chi(p) - 1), Chi = A101455. - _Jianing Song_, Oct 30 2019]
Expansion of (1 - theta_4(q)^2 * theta_4(q^2)^4)/4 in powers of q. - _Michael Somos_, Aug 09 2006
Expansion of (1-eta(q)^4*eta(q^2)^6/eta(q^4)^4)/4 in powers of q.

A002174.name: Values taken by reduced totient function psi(n).
formula: n (log n)^0.086 << a(n) << n (log n)^0.36 where << is the Vinogradov symbol, see Luca & Pomerance. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Dec 28 2013

A002175.name: Excess of number of divisors of 12n+1 of form 4k+1 over those of form 4k+3.
formula: Expansion of (phi(-x^3) / chi(-x))^2 in powers of x where phi(), chi() are Ramanujan theta functions.
Expansion of q^(-1/12) * (eta(q^2) * eta(q^3)^2 / (eta(q) * eta(q^6)))^2 in powers of q. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 19 2005
Euler transform of period 6 sequence [ 2, 0, -2, 0, 2, -2, ...]. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 19 2005
G.f. is a period 1 Fourier series which satisfies f(-1 / (72 t)) = 2 (t/i) g(t) where q = exp(2 Pi i t) and g() is the g.f. for A258279. - _Michael Somos_, May 25 2015

A002176.name: a(n) = LCM of denominators of Cotesian numbers {C(n,k), 0 <= k <= n}.

A002177.name: Numerators of Cotesian numbers (not in lowest terms): A002176(n)*C(n,0).

A002178.name: Numerators of Cotesian numbers (not in lowest terms): A002176*C(n,1).

A002179.name: Numerators of Cotesian numbers (not in lowest terms): A002176*C(n,2).

A002180.name: Values taken by the half-totient function phi(m)/2.

A002181.name: Least number k such that phi(k) = n, where n runs through the values (A002202) taken by phi.

A002182.name: Highly composite numbers, definition (1): numbers n where d(n), the number of divisors of n (A000005), increases to a record.
formula: Also, for n >= 2, smallest values of p for which A006218(p)-A006318(p-1) = A002183(n). - Philippe LALLOUET (philip.lallouet(AT)wanadoo.fr), Jun 23 2007
a(n+1) < a(n) * (1+log(a(n))^-c) for some positive c (see Erdős). - _David A. Corneth_, May 16 2016

A002183.name: Number of divisors of n-th highly composite number.
formula: Also record values of differences A006218(p)-A006218(p-1). These record values occur for any p = A002182(q) where q>=2. - Philippe LALLOUET (philip.lallouet(AT)wanadoo.fr), Jun 23 2007

A002186.name: Sprague-Grundy values for the game of Kayles (octal games .77 and .771).
formula: From n=71 on, the sequence is periodic with period 12. The only exceptions are n=0, 3, 6, 9, 11, 15, 18, 21, 22, 28, 34, 39, 57 and 70.

A002187.name: Sprague-Grundy values for Dawson's Chess (octal game .137).
formula: Has period 34 with the only exceptions at n=0, 14, 16, 17, 31, 34 and 51.

A002188.name: Sprague-Grundy values for Grundy's game.
formula: "Mike Guy has computed ten million values, but a discernible pattern remains elusive" [Guy, 1989]. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Jan 03 2016

A002189.name: Pseudo-squares: a(n) = the least nonsquare positive integer which is 1 mod 8 and is a (nonzero) quadratic residue modulo the first n odd primes.

A002190.name: Sum_{n>=0} a(n)*x^n/n!^2 = -log(BesselJ(0,2*sqrt(x))).
formula: Conjecture: G.f.: 1 = Sum_{n>=0} a(n+1)*A000108(n)*x^n*Sum_{k>=0} C(2*n+k,k)^2*(-x)^k. Compare with the following g.f of the Catalan numbers (A000108): 1 = Sum_{n>=0} A000108(n)*x^n*Sum_{k>=0} C(2*n+k,k)*(-x)^k. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Oct 10 2010
a(n) ~ n! * (n-1)! / r^n, where r = 1/4*BesselJZero[0,1]^2 = 1.44579649073669613... - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Mar 02 2014

A002191.name: Possible values for sum of divisors of n.
formula: a(n)/n < log_10(n) + O(1) with O(1) <= 1 for all n. - _M. F. Hasler_, Nov 22 2019

A002192.name: Least integer with A000203(a(n)) = A002191(n), where A002191 = range of the sum-of-divisors function A000203.

A002193.name: Decimal expansion of square root of 2.
formula: Sqrt(2) = 14 * Sum_{n >= 0} (A001790(n)/2^A005187(floor(n/2)) * 10^(-2n-1)) where A001790(n) are numerators in expansion of 1/sqrt(1-x) and the denominators in expansion of 1/sqrt(1-x) are 2^A005187(n). 14 = 2*7, see A010503 (expansion of 1/sqrt(2)). - _Gerald McGarvey_, Jan 01 2005
sqrt(2) = 2 + n*A167199(n-1)/A167199(n) as n -> infinity (conjecture). - _Mats Granvik_, Oct 30 2009
sqrt(2) = limit as n goes to infinity of A179807(n+1)/A179807(n) - 1. - _Mats Granvik_, Feb 15 2011

sqrt(2) = Product_{l=0..k-1} 2*cos((2*l+1)*Pi/(4*k)) = (Product_{l=0..k-1} R(2*l+1,rho(4*k)) - 1), identical for k >= 1, with the row polynomials R(n, x) from A127672 and rho(4*k) := 2*cos(Pi/(4*k)) is the length ratio (smallest diagonal)/side in a regular (4*k)-gon. From the product formula given in a Oct 21 2013 formula contribution to A056594, with n -> 2*k, using cos(Pi-alpha) = - cos(alpha) to obtain 2 for the square of the present product. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Oct 22 2013

sqrt(2) = lim_{n->infinity}(1/(1-Sum_{k=1..n}(((-1)^(k-1)*binomial(n-1, k-1))/f(k/n+s-1/n))/Sum_{k=1..n}(((-1)^(k-1)*binomial(n-1, k-1))/f(k/n + s)))+s) where f(x)=x^2-2 and s=1. - _Mats Granvik_, Apr 22 2021

A002194.name: Decimal expansion of sqrt(3).
formula: Equals Sum_{k>=0} binomial(2*k,k)/6^k = Sum_{k>=0} binomial(2*k,k) * k/6^k. - _Amiram Eldar_, Aug 03 2020

A002195.name: Numerators of coefficients for numerical integration.
formula: a(n) = numerator of (2/(2*n+1)!)*int(t*product(t^2-k^2, k=1..s), t=0..1). - _Emeric Deutsch_, Jan 25 2005

a(n) = numerator(sum(k=1..2*n, binomial(2*n+k-1,2*n-1)*sum(j=1..k, (binomial(k,j)*sum(i=0,j/2, (2*i-j)^(2*n+j)*binomial(j,i)*(-1)^(-i)))/(2^j*(2*n+j)!)))), n>0, a(0)=1. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Feb 04 2013

A002196.name: Denominators of coefficients for numerical integration.
formula: a(n) = denominator of (2/(2*n+1)!)*int(t*product(t^2-k^2, k=1..n), t=0..1). - _Emeric Deutsch_, Jan 25 2005
a(0) = 1; a(n) = denominator [sum((-1)^(k+n+1) * (B{2k}/(2*k)) * A008955(n-1, n-k), k = 1..n) / (2*n-1)!] for n >= 1. - _Johannes W. Meijer_, Jan 27 2009

A002197.name: Numerators of coefficients for numerical integration.
formula: Numerators of coefficients in expansion of 1/x-1/sqrt(x)/arcsin(sqrt(x)). - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Aug 11 2002

A002198.name: Denominators of coefficients for numerical integration.

A002199.name: Least negative primitive root of n-th prime.

A002201.name: Superior highly composite numbers: positive integers n for which there is an e > 0 such that d(n)/n^e >= d(k)/k^e for all k > 1, where the function d(n) counts the divisors of n (A000005).

A002202.name: Values taken by totient function phi(m) (A000010).

A002203.name: Companion Pell numbers: a(n) = 2*a(n-1) + a(n-2), a(0) = a(1) = 2.
formula: O.g.f.: (2 - 2*x)/(1 - 2*x - x^2). - _Simon Plouffe_ in his 1992 dissertation
a(n) = (1 + sqrt(2))^n + (1 - sqrt(2))^n. - Mario Catalani (mario.catalani(AT)unito.it), Mar 17 2003
Given F(n) = A000129(n), the Pell numbers, and L(n) = a(n), the companion Pell numbers, then:
G.f.: G(0), where G(k) = 1 + 1/(1 - x*(2*k - 1)/(x*(2*k + 1) - 1/G(k + 1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jun 19 2013
a(n) = A000129(n+1) + A000129(n-1) for n>0 with a(0)=2. - _Rigoberto Florez_, Jul 12 2020

A002204.name: An ill-conditioned determinant.
formula: a(n) ~ A^3 * 2^(n*(2*n-1) - 1/12) / (exp(1/4) * Pi^n * n^(3/4)), where A is the Glaisher-Kinkelin constant A074962. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Feb 24 2019

A002205.name: The RAND Corporation list of a million random digits.

A002206.name: Numerators of logarithmic numbers (also of Gregory coefficients G(n)).
formula: a(n)/A002207(n) = (1/n!) * Sum_{j=1..n+1} bernoulli(j)/j * S_1(n,j-1), where S_1(n,k) is the Stirling number of the first kind. - Barbara Margolius (b.margolius(AT)csuohio.edu), Jan 21 2002
G(n) = integrate(x=0..1, x*(x-n)_n)/(n+1)!, where (a)_n is the Pochhammer symbol. - _Vladimir Reshetnikov_, Oct 22 2015
a(n) = numerator(f(n+1)), where f(0) = 1, f(n) = Sum_{k=0..n-1} (-1)^(n-k+1) * f(k) / (n-k+1). - _Daniel Suteu_, Nov 15 2018

A002207.name: Denominators of logarithmic numbers (also of Gregory coefficients G(n)).
formula: A002206(n)/A002207(n) = 1/n! * Sum_{j=1..n+1} bernoulli(j)/j * S_1(n, j-1), where S_1(n,k) is the Stirling number of the first kind. - Barbara Margolius (b.margolius(AT)csuohio.edu), 1/21/02
G(n) = integrate(x=0..1, x*(x-n)_n)/(n+1)!, where (a)_n is the Pochhammer symbol. - _Vladimir Reshetnikov_, Oct 22 2015
a(n) = denominator(f(n+1)), where f(0) = 1, f(n) = Sum_{k=0..n-1} (-1)^(n-k+1) * f(k) / (n-k+1). - _Daniel Suteu_, Nov 15 2018

A002208.name: Numerators of coefficients for numerical integration.
formula: Let K_i = a(i)/A002209(i), for i >= 1, and [i n] = Stirling numbers of the first kind (A048994), {i n} = Stirling numbers of the second kind (A048993) and B_i the original Bernoulli numbers (A164555/A027642). Then K_i = ((-1)^(i-1) / (i-1)!)*Sum_{n=1..i} [i n]*B_n/n and B_i = i*Sum_{n=1..i} (-1)^(n-1)*{i n}*(n-1)!*K_n. - Rudi Huysmans, rudi_huysmans(AT)hotmail.com [see the second Mathematica program for K_n = a[n_] with B_k = (-1)^k * BernoulliB[k]. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Aug 09 2017]
a(n) = numerator(v(n)), where v(n) = 1 - Sum_{i=0..n-1} v(i)/(n-i+1), v(0)=1. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Aug 28 2013
a(n) = numerator((1/(n-1)!)*Sum_{k=0..n} ((-1)^(n-k)*binomial(2*n,n-k)*Stirling2(n+k,k))/(n+k)), n > 0, a(0)=1. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Apr 05 2016

A002209.name: Denominators of coefficients for numerical integration.
formula: a(n) = denominator(v(n)), where v(n) = 1 - Sum_{i=0..n-1} v(i)/(n-i+1), v(0)=1. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Aug 28 2013

A002212.name: Number of restricted hexagonal polyominoes with n cells.
formula: a(0)=1, for n > 0: a(n) = Sum_{j=0..n-1} Sum_{i=0..j} a(i)*a(j-i). G.f.: A(x) = 1 + x*A(x)^2/(1-x). - Mario Catalani (mario.catalani(AT)unito.it), Jun 19 2003
a(n) = Sum_{i=ceiling((n-1)/2)..n-1} (3^(2i+1-n)*binomial(n, i)*binomial(i, n-i-1))/n. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Jul 23 2002

a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} binomial(2k, k)*binomial(n-1, k-1)/(k+1), i.e., binomial transform of the Catalan numbers 1, 2, 5, 14, 42, ... (A000108). a(n) = Sum_{k=0..floor((n-1)/2)} 3^(n-1-2*k)*binomial(2k, k)*binomial(n-1, 2k)/(k+1). - _Emeric Deutsch_, Aug 05 2002
D-finite with recurrence: a(1)=1, a(n) = (3(2n-1)*a(n-1)-5(n-2)*a(n-2))/(n+1) for n > 1. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Dec 18 2002
a(n) is asymptotic to c*5^n/n^(3/2) with c=0.63.... - _Benoit Cloitre_, Jun 23 2003
In closed form, c = 1/2*sqrt(5/Pi) = 0.63078313050504... - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Oct 04 2012
a(n+1) = Sum_{k=0..n} 2^(n-k)*M(k)*binomial(n,k), where M(k) = A001006(k) is the k-th Motzkin number (from here it follows that a(n+1) and M(n) have the same parity). - _Emeric Deutsch_, May 10 2007
G.f.: 1/(1-z/(1-z/(1-z/(...)))) where z=x/(1-x) (continued fraction); more generally g.f. C(x/(1-x)) where C(x) is the g.f. for the Catalan numbers (A000108). - _Joerg Arndt_, Mar 18 2011
a(n) = upper left term in M^(n-1), M = an infinite square production matrix as follows, (with 3,2,2,2,...) as the main diagonal:
Alternatively, let M = the previous matrix but changing the 3 to a 2. Then a(n) = sum of top row terms of M^(n-1). (End)
a(n) = hypergeometric([1-n,3/2],[3],-4), for n>0. - _Peter Luschny_, Aug 15 2012
G.f.: Q(0), where Q(k)= 1 + (4*k+1)*x/((1-x)*(k+1) - x*(1-x)*(2*k+2)*(4*k+3)/(x*(8*k+6)+(2*k+3)*(1-x)/Q(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, May 14 2013
a(n) = GegenbauerC(n-1, -n, -3/2)/n for n >= 1. - _Peter Luschny_, May 09 2016
E.g.f.: 1 + Integral (exp(3*x) * BesselI(1,2*x) / x) dx. - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Jun 01 2020

A002213.name: Number of polyhexes rooted at a hexagon and containing n hexagons.

A002214.name: Number of unrooted hexagonal polyominoes with n cells and no reflections allowed.

A002215.name: Number of polyhexes with n hexagons, having reflectional symmetry (see Harary and Read for precise definition).
formula: G.f.: z+(1+2z)U(z^2) where U(z)=[1-3z-sqrt(1-6z+5z^2)]/(2z) (eq. (16) in the Harary-Read paper). a(2n)=A002212(n), n>=1; a(2n+1)=2*A002212(n), n>=1. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Mar 14 2004

A002216.name: Harary-Read numbers: restricted hexagonal polyominoes (cata-polyhexes) with n cells.

A002217.name: Starting with n, repeatedly calculate the sum of prime factors (with repetition) of the previous term, until reaching 0 or a fixed point: a(n) is the number of terms in the resulting sequence.

A002218.name: Number of unlabeled nonseparable (or 2-connected) graphs (or blocks) with n nodes.

A002219.name: a(n) is the number of partitions of 2n that can be obtained by adding together two (not necessarily distinct) partitions of n.
formula: See A213074 for Metropolis and Stein's formulas.

A002220.name: a(n) is the number of partitions of 3n that can be obtained by adding together three (not necessarily distinct) partitions of n.

A002221.name: a(n) is the number of partitions of 4n that can be obtained by adding together four (not necessarily distinct) partitions of n.

A002222.name: a(n) is the number of partitions of 5n that can be obtained by adding together five (not necessarily distinct) partitions of n.

A002223.name: Smallest prime p of form p = 8k-1 such that first n primes (p_1=2, ..., p_n) are quadratic residues mod p.

A002224.name: Smallest prime p of form p = 8k+1 such that first n primes (p_1=2, ..., p_n) are quadratic residues mod p.

A002225.name: a(n) is the smallest prime p such that each of the first n primes has three cube roots mod p.

A002226.name: Smallest prime p such that first n primes (p_1=2, ..., p_n) are quintic residues mod p.

A002227.name: Smallest prime p such that first n primes (p_1=2, ..., p_n) are 7th power residues mod p.

A002228.name: Smallest prime p such that first n primes (p_1=2, ..., p_n) are 11th power residues mod p.

A002229.name: Primitive roots that go with the primes in A002230.

A002230.name: Primes with record values of the least positive primitive root.

A002231.name: Primitive roots that go with the primes in A029932.

A002233.name: a(1) = 1; for n > 1, a(n) = least positive prime primitive root of n-th prime.
formula: a(n) = A122028(n) for n>1. - _Jonathan Sondow_, May 18 2017

A002234.name: Numbers k such that the Woodall number k*2^k - 1 is prime.

A002235.name: Numbers n such that 3*2^n - 1 is prime.

A002236.name: Numbers n such that 9*2^n - 1 is prime.

A002237.name: Numbers k such that 15*2^k - 1 is prime.

A002238.name: Numbers n such that 21*2^n-1 is prime.

A002240.name: Numbers n such that 33*2^n-1 is prime.

A002242.name: Numbers n such that 45*2^n-1 is prime.

A002243.name: Numbers that are not the sum of 3 distinct triangular numbers.

A002244.name: Numbers that are not the sum of 3 distinct nonzero triangular numbers.

A002246.name: a(1) = 3; for n > 1, a(n) = 4*phi(n); given a rational number r = p/q, where q>0, (p,q)=1, define its height to be max{|p|,q}; then a(n) = number of rational numbers of height n.

A002248.name: Number of points on y^2 + xy = x^3 + x^2 + x over GF(2^n).

A002249.name: a(n) = a(n-1) - 2*a(n-2) with a(0) = 2, a(1) = 1.
formula: a(n) = trace(A^n) for the square matrix A=[1, -2;1, 0]. - _Paul Barry_, Sep 05 2003
G.f.: G(0), where G(k)= 1 + 1/(1 - x*(7*k+1)/(x*(7*k+8) + 2/G(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jun 03 2013
a(n) = [x^n] ( (1 + x + sqrt(1 + 2*x - 7*x^2))/2 )^n for n >= 1. - _Peter Bala_, Jun 23 2015

A002251.name: Start with the nonnegative integers; then swap L(k) and U(k) for all k >= 1, where L = A000201, U = A001950 (lower and upper Wythoff sequences).

A002252.name: Order of letters on standard U.S. typewriter keyboard.

A002253.name: Numbers k such that 3*2^k+1 is prime.

A002254.name: Numbers k such that 5*2^k + 1 is prime.

A002255.name: Numbers n such that 7*4^n + 1 is prime.

A002256.name: Numbers k such that 9*2^k + 1 is prime.

A002257.name: Numbers n such that 13*4^n + 1 is prime.

A002258.name: Numbers k such that 15*2^k + 1 is prime.

A002259.name: Numbers k such that 17*2^k + 1 is prime.

A002260.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,k) = k for n >= 1, k = 1..n.
formula: n-th term is n - m*(m+1)/2 + 1, where m = floor((sqrt(8*n+1) - 1) / 2).
The above formula is for offset 0; for offset 1, use a(n) = n-m*(m+1)/2 where m = floor((-1+sqrt(8*n-7))/2). - _Clark Kimberling_, Jun 14 2011
a(k * (k + 1) / 2 + i) = i for k >= 0 and 0 < i <= k + 1. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Aug 14 2001
T(n,k) = Sum_{i=1..k} i*binomial(k,i)*binomial(n-k,n-i) (regarded as triangle, see the example). - _Mircea Merca_, Apr 11 2012
G.f.: x*y / ((1 - x) * (1 - x*y)^2) = Sum_{n,k>0} T(n,k) * x^n * y^k. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 17 2014

A002261.name: Numbers k such that 11*2^k+1 is prime.

A002262.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,k), 0 <= k <= n, in which row n lists the first n+1 nonnegative integers.
formula: a(n) = n - (trinv(n)*(trinv(n)-1))/2; trinv := n -> floor((1+sqrt(1+8*n))/2) (cf. A002024); # gives integral inverses of triangular numbers
a(n) = f(n,1) with f(n,m) = if n<m then n else f(n-m,m+1). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, May 20 2009
a(n) = (1/2)*(t - t^2 + 2*n), where t = floor(sqrt(2*n+1) + 1/2) = round(sqrt(2*n+1)). - _Ridouane Oudra_, Dec 01 2019

A002263.name: Numbers k such that 25*4^k + 1 is prime.

A002264.name: Nonnegative integers repeated 3 times.
formula: Complex representation: a(n) = (n - (1 - r^n)*(1 + r^n/(1 - r)))/3 where r = exp(2*Pi/3*i) = (-1 + sqrt(3)*i)/2 and i = sqrt(-1). - _Hieronymus Fischer_, Sep 18 2007; - corrected by _Guenther Schrack_, Sep 26 2019
For n >= 3, a(n) = floor(log_3(3^a(n-1) + 3^a(n-2) + 3^a(n-3))). - _Vladimir Shevelev_, Jun 22 2010
a(n) = (n - 3 + A010872(n-1) + A010872(n-2))/3 using Zumkeller's 2008 formula in A010872. - _Adriano Caroli_, Nov 23 2010
a(2*n) = A004523(n) and a(2*n+1) = A004396(n). - _L. Edson Jeffery_, Jul 30 2014
a(n) = n - 2 - a(n-1) - a(n-2) for n > 1 with a(0) = a(1) = 0. - _Derek Orr_, Apr 28 2015
a(n) = (3*n - 3 + r^n*(1 - r) + r^(2*n)*(r + 2))/9 where r = (-1 + sqrt(-3))/2. - _Guenther Schrack_, Sep 26 2019

A002265.name: Nonnegative integers repeated 4 times.
formula: a(n) = floor((n^4-1)/4*n^3) (n>=1); a(n) = floor((n^4-n^3)/(4*n^3-3*n^2)) (n>=1). - _Mohammad K. Azarian_, Nov 08 2007 and Aug 01 2009
For n>=4, a(n) = floor( log_4( 4^a(n-1) + 4^a(n-2) + 4^a(n-3) + 4^a(n-4) ) ). - _Vladimir Shevelev_, Jun 22 2010
a(n) = ceiling((n-3)/4), n >= 0. - _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, Jun 01 2013
a(n) = a(n-1) + a(n-4) - a(n-5) with initial values a(3)=0, a(4)=1, a(5)=1, a(6)=1, a(7)=1. - _David Neil McGrath_, Dec 04 2014

A002266.name: Integers repeated 5 times.
formula: Also, floor((n^5-1)/5*n^4) will produce this sequence. Moreover, floor((n^5-n^4)/(5*n^4-4*n^3)) (n >= 1) will produce this sequence as well. - _Mohammad K. Azarian_, Nov 08 2007
This sequence is also the sequence floor(n*e^(-(1+sqrt(5))/2))(n >= 1). - _Mohammad K. Azarian_, May 13 2008
For n >= 5, a(n) = floor(log_5(5^a(n-1) + 5^a(n-2) + 5^a(n-3) + 5^a(n-4) + 5^a(n-5))). - _Vladimir Shevelev_, Jun 22 2010

A002267.name: The 15 supersingular primes: primes dividing order of Monster simple group.

A002268.name: Dimensions of integral lattices that are irreducible modulo every prime (there may be missing terms!).

A002269.name: Numbers k such that 39*2^k + 1 is prime.

A002270.name: Composite n such that n*sigma(n) == 2 (mod phi(n)).

A002271.name: All odd numbers k, 1 < k < n, relatively prime to n are primes.

A002272.name: Theta series of 32-dimensional Quebbemann lattice Q_32.
formula: G.f.: b(x)^8 - 192*b(x)^4*d(x) + 576*d(x)^2 where b(x) is the g.f. of A004011 and d(x) is the g.f. of A002288. - _Sean A. Irvine_, Jul 26 2020

A002274.name: Numbers k such that 57*2^k+1 is prime.

A002275.name: Repunits: (10^n - 1)/9. Often denoted by R_n.
formula: Second binomial transform of Jacobsthal trisection A001045(3n)/3 (A015565). - _Paul Barry_, Mar 24 2004
G.f.: x/((1-10*x)*(1-x)). Regarded as base b numbers, g.f. x/((1-b*x)*(1-x)). - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Jun 15 2006
a(n) = A125118(n,9) for n>8. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Nov 21 2006
a(n) = a(n-1)+10^(n-1) with a(0)=0. - _Vincenzo Librandi_, Jul 22 2010

A002276.name: a(n) = 2*(10^n - 1)/9.
formula: a(n) = 10*a(n-1) + 2, with a(0) = 0. - _Paolo P. Lava_, Jan 23 2009
a(n) = a(n-1) + 2*10^(n-1) with a(0) = 0; Also: a(n) = 11*a(n-1) - 10*a(n-2) with a(0) = 0, a(1) = 2. - _Vincenzo Librandi_, Jul 22 2010

A002277.name: a(n) = 3*(10^n - 1)/9.
formula: a(n) = 10*a(n-1) + 3, with a(0)=0. - _Paolo P. Lava_, Jan 23 2009

A002278.name: a(n) = 4*(10^n - 1)/9.
formula: a(n)=10*a(n-1)+4, with a(0)=0. - _Paolo P. Lava_, Jan 23 2009

A002279.name: a(n) = 5*(10^n - 1)/9.
formula: a(n)=10*a(n-1)+5, with a(0)=0. - _Paolo P. Lava_, Jan 23 2009
a(n)=a(n-1)+5*10^(n-1) with a(0)=0; Also: a(n)=11*a(n-1)-10*a(n-2) with a(0)=0, a(1)=5. - _Vincenzo Librandi_, Jul 22 2010

A002280.name: a(n) = 6*(10^n - 1)/9.
formula: a(n) = 10*a(n-1) + 6, with a(n)=0. - _Paolo P. Lava_, Jan 23 2009
a(n) = a(n-1) + 6*10^(n-1) with a(0)=0. - _Vincenzo Librandi_, Jul 22 2010

A002281.name: a(n) = 7(10^n - 1)/9.
formula: a(n) = 10*a(n-1)+7 with n>0, a(0)=0. - _Paolo P. Lava_, Jan 23 2009
a(n) = a(n-1)+7*10^(n-1) with n>0, a(0)=0; also: a(n) = 11*a(n-1)-10*a(n-2) with n>1, a(0)=0, a(1)=7. - _Vincenzo Librandi_, Jul 22 2010

A002282.name: a(n) = 8*(10^n - 1)/9.
formula: a(n) = 10*a(n-1) + 8, with a(0)=0. - _Paolo P. Lava_, Jan 23 2009
a(n) = a(n-1) + 8*10^(n-1), with a(0)=0. - _Vincenzo Librandi_, Jul 22 2010

A002283.name: a(n) = 10^n - 1.
formula: G.f.: 1/(1-10*x)-1/(1-x). E.g.f.: e^(10*x)-e^x. - _Mohammad K. Azarian_, Jan 14 2009
a(n) = 10*a(n-1) + 9, with a(0)=0. - _Paolo P. Lava_, Jan 23 2009
a(n) = a(n-1) + 9*10^(n-1) with a(0)=0; Also: a(n) = 11*a(n-1) - 10*a(n-2) with a(0)=0, a(1)=9. - _Vincenzo Librandi_, Jul 22 2010
For n>0, A007953(a(n)) = A008591(n) and A010888(a(n)) = 9. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Aug 06 2010

A002284.name: q-expansion of modular form of weight 13/2: eta(8 tau)^12 * theta(tau).
formula: Expansion of eta(q^2)^5 * eta(q^8)^12 / (eta(q) * eta(q^4))^2 in powers of q.
Euler transform of period 8 sequence [ 2, -3, 2, -1, 2, -3, 2, -13, ...]. - _Michael Somos_, Mar 06 2004

A002285.name: Decimal expansion of common logarithm of e.

A002288.name: G.f.: q * Product_{m>=1} (1-q^m)^8*(1-q^2m)^8.
formula: Expansion of cusp form (e(1)-e(2))(e(1)-e(3))(e(2)-e(3))^2 for GAMMA_0(2).
Expansion of q * psi(q)^8 * phi(-q)^8 in powers of q where psi(), phi() are Ramanujan theta functions. - _Michael Somos_, Dec 09 2013
Expansion of (eta(q) * eta(q^2))^8 in powers of q. - _Michael Somos_, Mar 18 2003
a(n) is multiplicative with a(2^e) = (-8)^e, a(p^e) = a(p) * a(p^(e-1)) - p^7 * a(p^(e-2)). - _Michael Somos_, Mar 08 2006
Given A = A0 + A1 + A2 + A3 is the 4-section, then 0 = A2^3 + 2 * A0 * (A1^2 + A3^2) - 4 * A1*A2*A3 - 3 * A0^2*A2. - _Michael Somos_, Mar 08 2006
G.f. is a period 1 Fourier series which satisfies f(-1 / (2 t)) = 16 (t/i)^8 f(t) where q = exp(2 Pi i t). - _Michael Somos_, Apr 09 2013
a(2*n) = -8 * a(n). Convolution square of A030211. - _Michael Somos_, Apr 09 2013

A002289.name: Weight distribution of [ 23,12,7 ] binary perfect Golay code.

A002292.name: Related to representation as sums of squares.

A002293.name: Number of dissections of a polygon: binomial(4*n, n)/(3*n + 1).
formula: a(n) = binomial(4*n,n-1)/n, n >= 1, a(0) = 1. From the Lagrange series of the o.g.f. A(x) with its above given implicit equation.
a(n) = upper left term in M^n, M = the production matrix:
(where 1, 3, 6, 10, ...) is the triangular series. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Jul 08 2011
a(n) = binomial(4*n+1, n)/(4*n+1) = A062993(n+2,2). - _Robert FERREOL_, Apr 02 2015
a(n) = Sum_{i=0..n-1} Sum_{j=0..n-1-i} Sum_{k=0..n-1-i-j} a(i)*a(j)*a(k)*a(n-1-i-j-k) for n>=1; and a(0) = 1. - _Robert FERREOL_, Apr 02 2015
A(x)^2 is o.g.f. for A069271; A(x)^3 is o.g.f. for A006632;
A(x)^5 is o.g.f. for A196678; A(x)^6 is o.g.f. for A006633;
A(x)^7 is o.g.f. for A233658; A(x)^8 is o.g.f. for A233666;
A(x)^9 is o.g.f. for A006634; A(x)^10 is o.g.f. for A233667. (End)
E.g.f.: F([1/4, 1/2, 3/4], [2/3, 1, 4/3], 256*x/27], where F is the generalized hypergeometric function. - _Stefano Spezia_, Dec 27 2019

A002294.name: a(n) = binomial(5*n, n)/(4*n + 1).
formula: For the connection with the solution of the quintic, hypergeometric series, and Lagrange inversion, see Beukers (2014). - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Mar 12 2014
O.g.f. A(x) satisfies A(x) = 1 + x * A(x)^5 = 1 / (1 - x * A(x)^4).
Given g.f. A(x) then z = t * A(t^4) satisfies 0 = z^5 - z + t. - _Michael Somos_, Mar 17 2011
a(n) = binomial(5*n, n - 1)/n, n >= 1, a(0) = 1. From the Lagrange series of the o.g.f. A(x) with its above given implicit equation.
a(n) = upper left term in M^n, M = the production matrix:
(where (1, 4, 10, 20, ...) is the tetrahedral sequence, A000292. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Jul 08 2011
a(n) = binomial(5*n + 1, n)/(5*n + 1) = A062993(n+3,3). - _Robert FERREOL_, Apr 03 2015
a(0) = 1; a(n) = Sum_{i1 + i2 + ... + i5 = n - 1} a(i1) * a(i2) * ... *a(i5) for n >= 1. - _Robert FERREOL_, Apr 03 2015

A002295.name: Number of dissections of a polygon: binomial(6n,n)/(5n+1).
formula: a(n) = binomial(6*n,n-1)/n, n >= 1, a(0)=1. From the Lagrange series of the o.g.f. A(x) with its above given implicit equation.
a(n) = upper left term in M^n, M = the production matrix:
(where (1, 5, 15, 35, ...) = A000332 starting with 1. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Jul 08 2011
a(n) are special values of Jacobi polynomials, in Maple notation:
a(n) = JacobiP(n-1, 5*n+1, -n, 1)/n, n=1, 2, ... . - _Karol A. Penson_, Mar 17 2015
a(n) = binomial(6*n+1, n)/(6*n+1) = A062993(n+4,4). - _Robert FERREOL_, Apr 03 2015
a(0) = 1; a(n) = Sum_{i1+i2+...+i6=n-1} a(i1)*a(i2)*...*a(i6) for n>=1. - _Robert FERREOL_, Apr 03 2015

A002296.name: Number of dissections of a polygon: binomial(7n,n)/(6n+1).
formula: a(n) = binomial(7*n,n-1)/n, n>=1, a(0)=1. From the Lagrange series of the o.g.f. A(x) with its above given implicit equation.
a(n) are special values of Jacobi polynomials, in Maple notation:
a(n) = JacobiP(n-1, 6*n+1, -n, 1)/n, n=1, 2... . - _Karol A. Penson_, Mar 16 2015
a(n) = binomial(7*n+1, n)/(7*n+1) = A062993(n+5,5). - _Robert FERREOL_, Apr 02 2015
a(0) = 1; a(n) = Sum_{i1+i2+..+i7=n-1} a(i1)*a(i2)*...*a(i7) for n>=1. - _Robert FERREOL_, Apr 02 2015

A002300.name: Coefficients in the expansion of B^2*C^3 in Watson's notation of page 118.
formula: Expansion of q^(-23/24) * eta(q)^2 * eta(q^7)^3 in powers of q. - _Michael Somos_, May 31 2012
Euler transform of period 7 sequence [ -2, -2, -2, -2, -2, -2, -5, ...]. - _Michael Somos_, May 31 2012
G.f.: Product_{k>0} (1 - x^k)^2 * (1 - x^(7*k))^3. - _Michael Somos_, May 31 2012

A002301.name: a(n) = n! / 3.
formula: E.g.f. with offset = 0: 2/((1-x)^4). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Aug 16 2012
G.f. 2 + 8*x/(G(0)-4*x) where G(k) = x*(k+4) + 1 - x*(k+5)/G(k+1); (continued fraction, Euler's 1st kind, 1-step). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Aug 15 2012

A002303.name: Generalized tangent numbers.
formula: Ignoring the initial term a(4) = 16 and working with an offset of 0 the e.g.f. appears to be the rational function 16*(17+78*t+45*t^2)/(1-t)^10 = 272 + 3968*t + 56320*t^2/2! + .... - Peter Bala, Apr 23 2012

This rational function occurs in the series reversion (x-t*tan(x))^(-1) = x/(1-t) + 2*t/(1-t)^4*x^3/3! + 8*t*(2+3*t)/(1-t)^7*x^5/5! + 16*t*(17+78*t+45*t^2)/(1-t)^10*x^7/7! + ..., which is the e.g.f. for the triangle A059419 read by diagonals. - Peter Bala, Apr 23 2012

A002304.name: Numerators of coefficients in asymptotic expansion of (2/Pi)*Integral_{0..inf} (sin x / x)^n dx.

A002305.name: Denominators of coefficients in asymptotic expansion of (2/Pi)*Integral_{0..inf} (sin x / x)^n dx.

A002306.name: Numerators of Hurwitz numbers H_n (coefficients in expansion of Weierstrass P-function).
formula: Let P be the Weierstrass P-function satisfying P'^2 = 4*P^3 - 4*P. Then P(z) = 1/z^2 + Sum_{n>=1} 2^(4n)*H_n*z^(4n-2)/(4n*(4n-2)!).

A002307.name: Consecutive quadratic residues mod p: a(n)=maximal number of positive reduced quadratic residues which appear consecutively for n-th prime.

A002309.name: Sum of first n fourth powers of odd numbers.
formula: a(n) = v(n,n-2) - v(n,n-1)*V(n,n-1), where v(n,k) and V(n,k) are the central factorial numbers of the first kind and the second kind, respectively, with odd indices. - _Mircea Merca_, Jan 25 2014

A002310.name: a(n) = 5*a(n-1) - a(n-2).
formula: Sequences A002310, A002320 and A049685 have this in common: each one satisfies a(n+1) = (a(n)^2+5)/a(n-1). - _Graeme McRae_, Jan 30 2005

A002311.name: n-th tetrahedral number is the sum of 2 tetrahedral numbers.

A002312.name: Arc-cotangent reducible numbers or non-Størmer numbers: largest prime factor of n^2 + 1 is less than 2n.

A002313.name: Primes congruent to 1 or 2 modulo 4; or, primes of form x^2 + y^2; or, -1 is a square mod p.
formula: a(n) ~ 2n log n. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Jul 04 2016
a(n) = A002331(n)^2  + A002330(n)^2. See crossrefs. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Dec 11 2016

A002314.name: Minimal integer square root of -1 modulo p, where p is the n-th prime of the form 4k+1.

A002315.name: NSW numbers: a(n) = 6*a(n-1) - a(n-2); also a(n)^2 - 2*b(n)^2 = -1 with b(n)=A001653(n+1).
formula: a(n) = sqrt(2*(A001653(n+1))^2-1), n >= 0. [Pell equation  a(n)^2 - 2*Pell(2*n+1)^2 = -1. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Jul 11 2018]
G.f.: (1 + x)/(1 - 6*x + x^2). - _Simon Plouffe_ in his 1992 dissertation
a(n) = S(n, 6)+S(n-1, 6) = S(2*n, sqrt(8)), S(n, x) = U(n, x/2) are Chebyshev's polynomials of the 2nd kind. Cf. A049310. S(n, 6)= A001109(n+1).
Let q(n, x) = Sum_{i=0..n} x^(n-i)*binomial(2*n-i, i); then (-1)^n*q(n, -8) = a(n). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Nov 10 2002
With a=3+2*sqrt(2), b=3-2*sqrt(2): a(n) = (a^((2n+1)/2)-b^((2n+1)/2))/2. a(n) = A077444(n)/2. - Mario Catalani (mario.catalani(AT)unito.it), Mar 31 2003
Same as: i such that sigma(i^2+1, 2) mod 2 = 1. - Mohammed Bouayoun (bouyao(AT)wanadoo.fr), Mar 26 2004
a(n) = L(n, -6)*(-1)^n, where L is defined as in A108299; see also A001653 for L(n, +6). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jun 01 2005

P_{2n}+P_{2n+1} where P_i are the Pell numbers (A000129). Also the square root of the partial sums of Pell numbers: P_{2n}+P_{2n+1} = sqrt(Sum_{i=0..4n+1} P_i) (Santana and Diaz-Barrero, 2006). - _David Eppstein_, Jan 28 2007
a(n) = third binomial transform of 1, 4, 8, 32, 64, 256, 512, ... . - Al Hakanson (hawkuu(AT)gmail.com), Aug 15 2009
In general, a(n+k) = A001541(k)*a(n)) + sqrt(A001108(2k)*(a(n)^2+1)). See Sep 18 2007 entry above. - _Charlie Marion_, Dec 07 2011

(a(2n) + a(2n-1))/a(n) = 2*sqrt(2)*( (1 + sqrt(2))^(4*n) - (1 - sqrt(2))^(4*n))/((1 + sqrt(2))^(2*n+1) + (1 - sqrt(2))^(2*n+1)). [This was my solution to problem 5325, School Science and Mathematics 114 (No. 8, Dec 2014).] - _Henry Ricardo_, Feb 05 2015

The aerated sequence (b(n))n>=1 = [1, 0, 7, 0, 41, 0, 239, 0, ...] is a fourth-order linear divisibility sequence; that is, if n | m then b(n) | b(m). It is the case P1 = 0, P2 = -4, Q = -1 of the 3-parameter family of divisibility sequences found by Williams and Guy. See A100047.
a(n) = |Im(T(2n-1,i))|, i=sqrt(-1), T(n,x) is the Chebyshev polynomial of the first kind, Im is the imaginary part of a complex number, || is the absolute value. - _Leonid Bedratyuk_, Dec 17 2017
